publicationstmt.publisher: Marist College Archives and Special Collections

profiledesc.descrules: DACS Describing Archives: A Content Standard. Chicago: Society of American Archivists, 2013.

did.abstract: The Lowell Thomas Film Collection encompasses a wide range of materials documenting the travels of Lowell Thomas and Lowell Thomas Jr. These materials include 35mm motion picture prints and negatives, 16mm motion picture film and ¼ inch audio tape.

repository.corpname: Marist College Archives and Special Collections

accessrestrict.p: There are no restrictions on this collection

userestrict.p: Individuals requesting reproductions expressly assume the responsibility for compliance with all pertinent provisions of the Copyright Act, 17 U.S.C. ss101 et seq. Patrons further agree to indemnify and hold harmless the Marist College Archives & Special Collections and its staff in connection with any disputes arising from the Copyright Act, over the reproduction of material at the request of patrons. For more information please visit the following website: https://www.loc.gov/copyright/title17/.

bioghist.p: It was the declaration of war in 1917 that initiated Lowell Thomas’s travels across the globe. He would document what was happening on the war front and report back to his fellow Americans to aid in the war effort. Though after a short period of time filming the war efforts, Thomas felt his work would be better suited elsewhere and after given the opportunity to capture the British war in Arabia, he gladly accepted. While on this trip he met General Edmund Allenby and T.E. Lawrence. He spent days with Lawrence, photographing and filming him - materials that would later be used in one of Thomas’s travelogues.

Afterwards, Thomas continued his travels to Burma, India, Malaya, Europe and Russia. All the while filming, and documenting each journey. Many of these trips were presented to the public via travelogue productions and books that Thomas wrote. In 1930 Thomas became a radio broadcaster, presenting ‘Lowell Thomas and the News’ for 46 years on NBC and CBS radio.

Later, in 1954, Thomas along with a group of investors purchased majority control of the Hudson Valley Broadcasting Company. In just a few short years the company became known as Capital Cities Communications. With the purchase of a television station in Albany, New York and several radio stations Capital Cities became a national company. During his time with Cap Cities, as it came to be known, Thomas produced a series of travelogues under the name of ‘High Adventures with Lowell Thomas’. Places such as Russia, Nepal, New Guinea and Africa were just some of the areas of focus.

scopecontent.p: The Lowell Thomas Film Collection consists of video tapes and motion picture films arranged by form of material into two subseries. The subseries are divided further into sub subseries arranged by form of material or subject. Of particular interest are the motion picture films related to Thomas's Cinerama productions, the "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" series, and the journey to Tibet. Also of interest are the films of interviews and lectures given by Thomas or Lowell Thomas, Jr. A project to digitize these recordings is on-going. Materials without digital versions may be digitized at the researcher's expense. Researchers should consult with the archivist regarding the available digital versions.

prefercite.p: [Description of item, date, location of item in order of series, box number, folder number ], in the Lowell Thomas Film Collection, Archives and Special Collections, James A. Cannavino Library, Marist College.

arrangement.p: Collection is arranged into nineteen series: 1) Africa, 2) Alaska, 3) Arctic, 4) Australia, 5) Belgian Congo, 6) Danger Island, 7) India, 8) Intros, 9) Nepal, 10) New Guinea, 11) Russia, 12) Sinbad, 13) Tibet, 14) Venezuela, 15) Atomic, 16) Bertha Vester, 17) Cinerama, 18() East Asia, and 19) Home Movies

custodhist.p: The Lowell Thomas Film Collection was donated to Marist College by the Thomas family in 2006 and 2013.

note.p: The Marist College Archives and Special Collections staff wishes to express their deep appreciation to all of the parties that helped the Lowell Thomas Project come to fruition. [Read more](https://archives.marist.edu/LTPHistoricalNote/views/acknowledgements.html)

scopecontent.p: We are shown an African village surrounded by a fortress. The women of the village gather straw into a large pile. The camera focuses on the women's many piercings and body modifications. The men of the village continue to built their huts and fortress. An American military man plays with his dog in the village. Men prepare for a fight and aim their guns and spears over the fort. Shots of snowy mountains.; Format: 16mm; Picture: Black & White; Audio: ; Type: Positive

Audio only. Lowell Thomas reports "live" from the "Concourse of Sinners" in Marrakesh, Morocco. Entertainers performing on the street encourage passerby's to "not be stingy with their contributions." Lowell Thomas interviews American children who live in Morocco. One at a time, he asks them what their fathers do for a living. Lowell describes a little Moroccan girl at the square who had just reached womanhood at 13. She picks out a celebratory veil. Lowell Thomas narrates the process of men dying fabrics and leather. ; Format: 16mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

scopecontent.p: "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas". (last reel of this episode) Directred by Victor Stoloff. In this episode, Lowell Thomas meets taxidermist Zimmerman. He then travels to Madagascar, where he witnesses its inhabitants celebrating the continuation of life in death by digging up their deceased ancestors, as well as the rituals surrounding a couple getting married. Contains concluding message by sponsor, General Motors Delco-Remy batteries, a preview for the next episode of "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" in Tibet, and closing credits. Copyright 1958.; Format: 16mm; Picture: Black & White; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

African men, women and children gather beneath palm trees. They sing along to drum beats. A man constructs a drum out of wood and stretched leather. A large group of men pray together. A woman picks sap from a plant and places it into her baby's mouth and around it's body. Cut to a woman painting her baby's face with clay in order to ward off flies. We watch a rattle snake coil in a bush and travel across the desert sand. Cut to the camera capturing the patterns in the sand the snake has left. Women grind up leaves and berries by hammering it with stone.; Format: 16mm; Picture: Color; Audio: ; Type: Positive

Full episode of "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" in Africa. Directred by Victor Stoloff. In this episode, Lowell Thomas explores African superstitions, beginning with witch doctors in Timbuktu, Mali. He moves on to scenes of Lowell Thomas, Jr. and Mary Taylor "Tay" Thomas attending a Watusi dance. Lowell Thomas then explains the enormous importance of salt in the region and quickly visits the Pygmies before meeting taxidermist Zimmerman. He then travels to Madagascar, where he witnesses its inhabitants celebrating the continuation of life in death by digging up their deceased ancestors, as well as the rituals surrounding a couple getting married. Copyright 1958.; Format: 16mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

Full episode of "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" in Africa. Directred by Victor Stoloff. In this episode, Lowell Thomas explores African superstitions, beginning with witch doctors in Timbuktu, Mali. He moves on to scenes of Lowell Thomas, Jr. and Mary Taylor "Tay" Thomas attending a Watusi dance. Lowell Thomas then explains the enormous importance of salt in the region and quickly visits the Pygmies before meeting taxidermist Zimmerman. He then travels to Madagascar, where he witnesses its inhabitants celebrating the continuation of life in death by digging up their deceased ancestors, as well as the rituals surrounding a couple getting married. Copyright 1958.; Format: 16mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

Full episode of "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" in Morocco. Directed by Victor Stoloff. Lowell Thomas travels all over Morocco, from the harem of __ in Marrakech to the Sahara to the Atlas Mountains. He witnesses a wedding at Roman ruins north of the Atlas Mountains, entertainers in Marrakech, and a tannery. Copyright 1958.; Format: 16mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

scopecontent.p: Lowell Thomas narrates his journey in Timbuktu in Morocco. He describes the camel trading business as he watches merchants bargaining and he describes the oasis that needs to be maintained daily to keep the desert from ruining it. In Marakesh at the foot of the Atlas mountains, he mentions the Muslim call to prayer, the fine leather, and the hand crafted gems of the town. The entertainers in the square dance and one man picks up needles with his eyelids. At the end of the film, Thomas is headed off to the Himalayas in northern India.; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical, Magnetic; Type: Positive

did.unittitle: Capital Cities Lowell Thomas Head Pix "High Adventure"Theatrical Reel 4 (slop print) HD pix

scopecontent.p: Lowell Thomas narrates as men go to Sheeba to trade, Zanzibar for salt and cloves, men run in a bull fight and sail in their dhows to trade pearls, and men embark on their journey to solve the Lasseter mystery in Australia. 27 years after the disappearance of Harold Lasseter, Thomas travels to figure out where he went. An aboriginal man recalls seeing Lasseter being buried in the desert and they journey off into the heart of Australia to find his remains. Along the way, the men invent different contraptions and methods to deter the tormenting flies and Thomas asks about Mountain Devils. The Aborigini hunters are shown teaching their boys how to track, hunt, throw spears, make boomerangs, and find water. At the end of the film, Lasseter's skull is found and Thomas suggests a monument be built in his honor. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: Black & White; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

scopecontent.p: In the Congo, Lowell Thomas passes by African ice mountains and a volcano, describing the hippos and immense trees. He stays in a village where a white man, renowned for his crocodile and hippo hunting had married a village girl and watched as a crew of them hunted a hippo who had been bothering their boats. In another village, they visit an English anthropologist who was with the Pygmies, and he describes the Pygmy boys' initiation and how a group of them made a vine bridge to cross a crocodile-infested river to get honey. Thomas then travels to Morocco where he describes the camel trading business, a man practicing primitive psychiatry, oasis maintenance in the desert, Moroccan leather, story-telling, prayer, and entertainment in the Marakesh square. In the end, Thomas heads off into the Himalayas of northern India.; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color, Black & White, N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Optical, Magnetic; Type: Positive

High Adventures with Lowell Thomas. Lofty mountains. Traditions and daily life in a village of Hippo Hunters. Lowell Thomas travels with a caravan on camels in the Sahara. Women shopping for veils in the markets in Morocco. Tanners of Marrakesh. Concourse of sinners is now the center of show business, fire breathers, dancers and performers. Daily life in Timbuktu. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color, Black & White; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

Lowell Thomas talks about camels and the prophet Mohammed before going to the market place. Salt merchant measures slab of salt to ensure he doesn't get ripped off. Group of men travel through desert.; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

LT describes rituals in Madagascar. He says that the London missionary failed to change these local custom. The traditions surrounding death is that their ancestors are not really dead. On certain days, bodies are taken out of the grave, dressed in a new shroud and fed food. There is singing and dancing, and eventually the bodies are put back in the grave. The night before a wedding, a Madagascan groom must become blood brothers with his bride's male family. This is done in a ritualistic cutting and mixing of blood.; Format: 35mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: ; Type: Positive

Lowell Thomas speaks to the camera from a desk in front of a map of Timbuktu. In Timbuktu, the film shows men with swords and trinkets around their necks, women displaying cased artifacts and medals, men constructing buildings with mud and clay, men reading and writing, camels being checked and sold, women playing music, and a man measuring out a clay tablet. At the end of the film, Thomas is shown meeting someone in Fort Bonnier. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: Black & White; Audio: ; Type: Positive

The audio records a piece of Lowell Thomas's invitation to travel to Timbuktu and his brief mention of the Moors. Other parts of the film feature bird sounds. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

LT describes the salt caravan route through the Sahara. The Tuareg worriers hijack these caravans, so many of the caravans have armed guards. Tuareg worriers are veiled, and the Tuareg women are unveiled. They veil nevertheless to prevent evil spirits from entering their nose and mouth. In Timbuktu there is a missionary family with their children LT tells the story of the teams "script girl"--- a 60 year old women that joined LT and the camera crew. She used to be a music teacher in California, but wanted adventure. LT and the crew then go to the Congo where they meet the Pygmy. The Pygmy dont cut down trees because they believe that where there ancestor's spirits live. LT then takes a trip up the white Nile. He meets a tribe that have been driven away from their village by Tsetse flies. Their witch doctors says that he can chase the flies away, but he needs some ancestors bones from the abandoned village. LT joins a few men from the tribe on their mission to find the ancestors bones. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

Men, riding elephants with their cargo, stroll past a train station and into a village. Other men carry baskets, ride their bikes, and push wagons into the village where they set up a market. Men get their hair cut, produce is sold, men play games with parrots. A man and a boy play the drums and a flute while a man from the film crew records it and plays it back for them. Another man takes a picture of a younger man standing in front of a wagon and gives him the picture afterwards. At the end of the film the crew packs up and leaves on their elephants. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: Black & White; Audio: ; Type: Positive

Lowell Thomas talks about the overwhelmingly, at least for him, primitive nature of the Moroccan people who continue to rely on the camel to cross their vicious sand dunes and have no interest in the modern technology that the world is advancing towards. He describes the barren land, saying that the land was fertile and lush during the Ice Age of Europe but now only has a few green patches left, with the oasis needing to be maintained daily lest the desert take that over too. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

Lowell Thomas speaks about the wildlife of the Sahara by describing an encounter between a viper, lizard, and a skunk. He details the holes in the desert that connect spring waters to the people in the area before imagining a future in which they will surrender their primitive ways to the technology of mills and tractors. He briefly mentions a Muslim school where they do not spare the rod and then describes the healing processes that people go through when they are received at the Tomb of Marabout. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

Lowell Thomas describes the traditions of people in the Sahara by detailing the camel, the people's tents and their devotion to dance. He illustrates their story telling at the foot of the Atlas mountains and describes the market that the people go to to sell their pottery. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

Lowell Thomas narrates a description of culture in the Sahara. He describes the wildlife by talking about the interaction between a viper, lizard, and skunk. He then speaks about how holes in the desert are used to connect springs to the people in the area and imagines modernization through mills and tractors. After a brief description of a Muslim school he talks about the Tomb of Marabout, where people go to receive healing. The film ends just as he is getting into talking about beauty parlors. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

Lowell Thomas narrates the procedures the barber surgeon at the Atlas Mountain marketplace must perform. He explains that barbers were traditionally our surgeons in Medieval times. The barber prepares a patient for blood-letting. Then, he performs other body modifications on several customers. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

The film begins in Morocco where a fire eater in a crowded square drinks boiling water to cool down the fire he just ate. Men are shown making leather which is laid out to dry over the rooftops of buildings covering several streets. A military parade is held, polo is played, a canoe race is ran, and Lowell Thomas stands by watching next to crates of Delco materials. He's shown riding elephants and trapping a tiger in Tibet and digging up bones in Australia. Lowell Thomas speaks to the camera in front of a map where he points to each location. A Delco commercial plays just before the title screen of "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" and the credits roll.; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: ; Type: Positive

Different clips depicting different scenes from the Sahara desert. The first several clips show a group of Berbers playing traditional music, they are all men and all are dressed in white. The rest of the clips are set in the city of Timbuktu in Mali. The footage shows LT touring the city. There is footage of the cities river port, as well as its salt markets. The last couple of clips depict what appears to be a staged fight of men (bandits and guards) on camels. Both groups are armed, but no one uses their weapons, rather, they to wrestle each other off the camels. Much of the this footage it narrated by LT. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

Footage of Marrakesh. LT narrates a scene of a Moroccan girl buying her first veil in the market. The next several clips show small girls weaving carpets in a factory. Next are scenes of a leather tannery. One tanner sings a love song as he works, LT says. The footage shows many hides hanging out to dry on the sides of buildings. The last couple of clips are of the main square in Merrakesh. There is footage of the different street performer playing drums, dancing and performing magic tricks. One man's magic trick is that he drinks boiling water. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

"High Adventure with Lowell Thomas." (Audio only.) Lowell speaks to us from "inside a crevice in the ice." He tells is that the 49th state is home to to the World's largest carnivorous animal: the brown bear. He goes on to explain to us the different customs of an Eskimo tribe, and the differences between them and other tribes. He talks about different transportation opportunities. (How we can get to and from the state and how we can get to different locations within the state.) Up-to-date farming ensures the best foods will get shipped to local supermarkets. He takes us to a ragtime-themed restaurant. We listen to the songs they play. He is with scientists studying a deep crevice in a glacier. The scientists say it is important to study icebergs because it is a good indication of what the weather will be like in the future. Lowell Thomas interviews a helicopter pilot from inside a helicopter. The pilot explains that his job is very safe because he has a very qualified rescue team.; Format: 16mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

did.unittitle: Chamber of Commerce Alaska America's Brightest Star Neg Cuts

scopecontent.p: We are shown a map of Alaska. Two fighter jets fly in unison. Two planes take off with parachutes lagging behind them. Eskimo men carve stones. Close up of Lowell Thomas Jr. speaking to the camera. Men ski and weave between flags. A woman and children shop in the produce section of a grocery store. A man stands next to a giant head of lettuce and a giant radish. Men exit a Weir Alaska plane and are greeted by Alaskan dancers. Men cut down trees and pull them with a rope. A man climbs up a tree by wrapping a rope around a truck. Close up of an oil drill. We are shown a totem pole. Cut to a shot of the American flag. Words appear on the screen: "This has been a presentation of Alaska Bankers Association, Alaska state Chamber of Commerce." Cut to a shot of a totem pole. Screen: Alaska, America's Brightest Star. ; Format: 16mm; Picture: Color; Audio: ; Type: Positive

We see blue-ribbon winning giant lettuce and radish.; Format: 16mm; Picture: Color; Audio: ; Type: Positive

did.unittitle: Lowell Thomas Jr. Alaska - America's Brightest Star Mag. Narration

scopecontent.p: Audio only. We hear snippets of narration for a documentary about Alaska. He begins with talking about the Alaskan gold rush. "Alaska: America's Brightest Star." He describes a town fish wheel that can catch 400 salmon a day. The Eskimos make fur parkas made of seal skin. He describes a bull Moose and it's calf. He explains to us how oil is Alaska's newest and brightest industry. A man conducts an orchestra. Indian dancers reenact a dramatic story in which their chief is killed by a bear. He tells us that the Supermarket imports food from everywhere for the Alaskan housewife. Fresh bear tracks leading into a meadow. The hunters miss their chance to shoot the bear. ; Format: 16mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

scopecontent.p: Students line up in their graduation caps and gowns. A man speaks to us from behind a desk. Scientists work with students in a lab. We are shown a map of Alaska. Sign: "Douglas Marine Station of the University of Alaska." We see icebergs collapsing. Men sail by the glaciers in a boat. We see whale tails peaking out of the water. Men pull sea urchins out of shallow pools of water. they then collect a sample of sand. Cut to a college basketball game. Teachers watch over a kindergarten class. Cows line up in a barn to be milked. We see ferrets in cages. Men and women try mining for gold using silver pans. ; Format: 16mm; Picture: Black & White; Audio: ; Type: Positive

They find large a large crab and stick it in their bucket. Cut to miners shoveling dirt into a cart. Cut to a college basketball game. We are shown all sorts of wildlife and animals. Sign: Arctic Research Laboratory. Scientists observe jars of water. Cut to men sitting in class listening to a professor. We see the Northern Lights shining over a school building. A giant satellite is pointed towards the sky.; Format: 16mm; Picture: Black & White; Audio: ; Type: Positive

On the audio track people was talking about Great Britain, Russia, France and Germany. They were talking about the balance of power and that Europe was table until the Franco Prussian war. They also talked about problems in terms of international politics and unsettled situations. They also talked about Cuba, and Castro having large plantations such as sugar plantations and the he had peasants from South America who worked for him. They also talked about communism, fascism, democracy and dictatorship. One person said ambition must be made to counteract ambition. They talked about what the world would of been like if Hitler had conquered all of Europe. They also talked about the allied powers and that they waited to long to protect the nation. Someone also talked about biological science, physical science and scientific programs. Someone then talked about Alaska being the key stone, talked about the University of Alaska and that it holds the purpose of becoming a free world center for all baisc aspects of arctic research and study. ; Format: 16mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

A station with the American Flag waving, in the middle of an icy tundra is shown with men walking around and measuring things. Aerial views of mountains, rivers, forests, homes, and buildings are shown. Several different scenes are ran through; cranes and trunks excavating an area; men on a boat crab fishing; a totem pole; men in suits playing poker; boats on a small dock; men riding bulls; horses racing; people skiing; men with hunting guns smoking cigarettes around a fire; a man fishing off a shore; William A. Egan sitting at his desk; "Tay" Thomas speaking with people; a man displays his artifacts; animals in the wild; dogs pulling a car and scenes of dog sledding. A plane flying above the station mentioned before and a single man holding a sign that says "Go Home Yankee". A scene of a play with people dressed as Native Americans. A short clip of the northern lights and a man falling off a sled. A helicopter drops down a car for a group of men in the snow near a station. A man squatting next to a paw print in front of the station speaks to the camera. The graduation ceremony and campus of the University of Alaska is shown. The film ends with animals in the wild playing with their young. ; Format: 16mm; Picture: Black & White; Audio: ; Type: Positive

A man/scientist analyzes his plants with a magnifying glass (looks like corn). A crowd of men and women are using a high power water hose/pipe to clear out some land in a valley. did.unittitle: HAWLT Alaska - The Last Frontier Part 1 (2 parts)

scopecontent.p: First part of Alaska episode of "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas." In this episode, Lowell Thomas visits Alaska, which has only recently become the 49th state. He is joined by Lowell Thomas, Jr., Mary Taylor "Tay" Thomas, and their young daughter Anne Thomas as he visits Juneau, the Matanuska Valley, glaciers, and Anchorage mainly by air. He also visits with old friends Jack McCourt and ski champion Gretchen Fraser. Includes commercials by sponsor General Motors Delco-Remy batteries.; Format: 16mm; Picture: Black & White; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

Second part of Alaska episode of "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas." Directed by Jean-Philippe Carson. Produced by Lowell Thomas, Jr. under executive producer Lowell Thomas. Lowell Thomas, Jr., Mary Taylor "Tay" Thomas, and Anne Thomas have to make a forced landing and be rescued. Meanwhile, Lowell Thomas narrates as he and others ski the glaciers, then moves on to narrate the life of Eskimos, including a walrus hunt. Contains commercials by sponsor General Motors Delco-Remy batteries, as well as a preview for the next episode of "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" in the Belgian Congo. Copyright 1958.; Format: 16mm; Picture: Black & White; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

Second part of "The Journey of Robert Falcon Scott", an Odyssey production in cooperation with the Navy Museum and the Royal Geographic Society of London. Narrated by Charles Collingwood. Directed by John Desmond. Produced by Charles Romone. This film recreates Scott's disasterous 1911-12 Antarctic expedition to the South Pole. After paring his expedition down to five men, Scott reaches the South Pole to discover that they were not the first group to make it there and they begin the deadly journey back to the north.; Format: 16mm; Picture: Black & White; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

Full episode of "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" in Alaska. Directed by Jean-Philippe Carson. Produced by Lowell Thomas, Jr. under executive producer Lowell Thomas. In this episode, Lowell Thomas visits Alaska, which has only recently become the 49th state. He is joined by Lowell Thomas, Jr., Mary Taylor "Tay" Thomas, and their young daughter Anne Thomas as he visits Juneau, the Matanuska Valley, glaciers, and Anchorage mainly by air. He also visits with old friends Jack McCourt and ski champion Gretchen Fraser. Lowell Thomas, Jr., Mary Taylor "Tay" Thomas, and Anne Thomas have to make a forced landing and be rescued. Meanwhile, Lowell Thomas narrates as he and others ski the glaciers, then moves on to narrate the life of Eskimos, including a walrus hunt. Copyright 1958.; Format: 16mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

did.unittitle: Capital Cities Lowell Thomas High Adventure Reel 8

scopecontent.p: Many different clips of Alaska. Many of the clips are scenes of the arctic. LT goes on an expedition with a group of scientist to measure the depth of glaciers in order to determine historical weather patterns. This expedition includes scenes of glaciers crumbling into the sea, the scientist's camp, and of the group skying. Several of the clips is of two old men from Yugoslavia who come to Alaska during the gold rush. They live in a remote cabin, ans still mine for gold. LT visits them and the surrounding area including a visit to the local saloon.Clips also include a plane trip with LT Jr. and his wife Tay and their daughter Mary. There are also clips of Alaskan wild life (bears, beavers, and moose) and of Alaskan native people, including a scene of a Inuit walrus hunt. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: Black & White; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

Lowell visits a remote scientific outpost on skis. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color, Black & White; Audio: Optical, Magnetic; Type: Positive

did.unittitle: Last Frontier - R5, R5 roll A Alaska, new version

scopecontent.p: People ski around, Lowell Thomas among them. Shots of entire crew skiing down slope one by one. Shot of mountains. Map is shown. Shot of terrain and then family in plane. Hunter comes home to family. Shots of mother examining dog and looking over baby as it sleeps. Hunter crafts a mask. Two women sit behind sewing machine. Man uses grass slabs to build around tent. Eskimos prepare to hunt for walruses. They get on boats and embark. A man emulates a walruses call. They row towards hoard of walruses and attack.; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

did.unittitle: High Adventure- Odyssey- Productions- The Last Frontier

scopecontent.p: Men hike through snow. One of them get stuck but the others help him up. They return to camp. Lowell Thomas is eating with others within a tent. He then returns to his private tent to sleep. 2 men take belongings out of a plane before a woman and little girl join them. In a plane, 2 men talk. Shot of nature. The plan lands and the two men walk out with sacks on their backs. They sit in the kitchen with elderly men. One of them puts on the radio. Another one starts weighing items (seeds and batteries probably). Shot of snowy mountain, girl and mom on plane. More shots of terrain.; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: ; Type: Positive
Audio Track: Water dripping, bear growling, birds chirping.; Format: 35mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive
Audio Track: Lowell Thomas talking about Alaska over and over in different takes.; Format: 35mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

Shots of walruses on ice. Eskimos on boats throws spears and shoot at them. They return to the ice and pull in a dead walrus. Shots of terrain. Chunks of ice failing off cliffs. Shots of baby seals. Lowell Thomas talks to camera. Shots of terrain and animals. Credits begin.; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

did.unittitle: Alaska Last Frontier High Adventure Odyssey

scopecontent.p: Lowell Thomas sends LT Jr. and Mary Taylor "Tay" Thomas to Alaska, Lowell Thomas highlights several people who found success in Alaska, Many people speak about Alaska and how good they think it is, Alaskan social life is also shown at a saloon; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

scopecontent.p: Ship sails on icy sea. A man on board looks through his binoculars before pointing at something. Another man talks into a device. Shots of men on ship performing different tasks. They lower a couple of barrels onto a boat. A tank drives onto shore. Lowell Thomas talks to camera while standing next to a man. Eskimos dancing, laughing, and jumping on trampoline. Plane flying. Lowell Thomas talks to man again. Shots of terrain. Lowell Thomas greets other people. They aboard a sled attached to a tank and take off. At camp they deal with a large object that looks like a rocket. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: Black & White; Audio: ; Type: Positive

Men sitting at tables in room. Man operates machinery. Men suddenly shoot out of their seats and rush to jets. They take off into the sky. A jet gets hit by something and explodes. Lowell Thomas talks to camera. Shot of a map. People board a jet with their belongings, waving goodbye. Lowell Thomas talks to 2 other men. Shots of jet flying and icy water. Men in diving suits walk along the ice before jumping onto the water. An explosion in the water occurs.; Format: 35mm; Picture: Black & White; Audio: ; Type: Positive

did.unittitle: Alaska Last Frontier Odyssey High Adventure Reel # 4 Roll A

scopecontent.p: Tent and small plane sit next to lake. Little girl by lake, wetting sock in lake as a man observes the plane. The girl goes into the woods and sees a squirrel. A beaver chews on sticks in the river and swims. The girl sees a baby moose. She sees another baby moose and tries feeding it a leaf and washing its face with a washcloth. The baby moose ends up trying to eat the washcloth. Shot of adult moose crossing river and wandering onto land. Man looks at plane engine. He calls for help but gets no response. He tries again and is successful. A plane flies through the sky, trying to find the man who called. The plane lands and the man figures out what was wrong with the malfunctioning plane. They take off. A plane lands in snow. Lowell Thomas comes out of the plane with two others. We see him use a device in the snow.; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

did.unittitle: High Adventure with Lowell Thomas - Odyssey Alaska

scopecontent.p: Shots of mountains. People dive off ice and into water. Overview of land. Lowell Thomas talks to camera as men operate technology/machines in the background. Tank-like vehicle pulls up in front of dome-shaped building. Lowell Thomas Jr. (?) walks down hallway, enters a room and sits down at a table with men in suits/uniforms. In a different scene, a group plays pool, a man gets his hair shaved, and people in a small closet play instruments. Lowell Thomas Jr. (?)climbs ladder into a room with big, weird, object that looks like a radio tower.,; Format: 35mm; Picture: Black & White; Audio: ; Type: Positive

The film title, "Frozen Jungle," showed Lowell Thomas and other men getting on a U.S Air Force Plane. It showed people on boats working, it showed ice glaciers falling and it showed sea lions.; Format: 35mm; Picture: Black & White; Audio: ; Type: Positive

The film starts off with images of mountains and valleys before showing men, carrying their skis and trudging through snow. Near a river where a bear is fishing, a couple of men pan for gold. Lowell Thomas Jr. sits in a cabin with them as they weigh their treasure and talk to him. On a U.S. Air Force base, Lowell Thomas speaks to military officials and meets a few soldiers.; Format: 35mm; Picture: Black & White; Audio: ; Type: Positive

The beginning scene shows a celebration as a crowd of people gather around others dancing and singing. Other people are shown crafting as a man makes a mask, men hollow out logs, men and women weave baskets and a few young men pull a vine from one tree to another over a river with crocodiles. Young kids play a spearing game where an object is swung around a circle of kids who try to spear the object as it swings past. Clips of women dancing and people celebrating as well as what looks like a bull run, are played. Islanders play cricket and chase a chicken near the beach. The ending scene shows a man sitting in a circle of children as the children read from tablets. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: Black & White; Audio: ; Type: Positive

Several different audio clips of LT describing Alaska. The clips include LT describing and interviewing farmer that received free parcels of Alaskan land in exchange for being "pioneers" of the new state. Another set of clips, LT describes a old saloon in a mining town where a women named "Hattie" plays piano. Hattie wears a vest of silver dollars and used to play piano in casinos. Several of the clips include LT describing his experiences on a expedition with scientist who are measuring glaciers. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

did.unittitle: Cap Cities L Thomas High Adv Reel 5 Theatrical Mixtrack A

scopecontent.p: Lowell Thomas narrates his adventure to the North Pole with renowned explorers, Donald McMillan, Colonel Bolkin, and Sir Hubert Wilkins. They stop at a data collection site where Thomas speaks with an Austrian scientist about life in the Arctic and the dangers of ice breakage. Frog men are sent underwater to place explosives on an ice jam to allow Navy supply ships through. McMillan toasts the men and comments on the differences between travelling to the Arctic on dog sleds in 1909 and travelling there on an airplane. When they reach true north, the men salute those who died on their way to the top. They drop a wreath into the water and spread the ashes of Peter Freuchen who started out with them but died on the journey. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color, N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Optical, Magnetic; Type: Positive

did.unittitle: (Arctic/Tibet) Dialog Track Reel 5 Theatrical "L. Thomas" "High Adventure"

scopecontent.p: On the audio track you hear Lowell Thomas talking about taking a trip to the North Pole with two explorers. You also hear other men talking about there trip to the North Pole and you hear Lowell Thomas giving a toast and other men giving toast also. You hear Lowell Thomas talking about the people of Tibet and you hear Lowell Thomas Jr., talking about his father being carried by Tibetans because he broke his hip and they were on a journey to India. You hear Lowell Thomas saying it took them 20 days to get to India ; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical, Magnetic; Type: Positive

Men walking in North Pole Camp. Lowell Thomas and other men talk outside in the cold. Now inside, a group of men, including Lowell Thomas, sit at a table and talk to one another. A plane flies through the sky, approaching the North Pole. Lowell Thomas and other men do a toast. Lowell Thomas drops flowers as the plane flies by in memory of those who died.; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

did.unittitle: Arctic R-6 / R-3 Odyssey P.101 - Alaska - Studio Print

scopecontent.p: Shots of icy terrain. Man ejects out of aircraft, reaches ground safely. Another man ejects also, but the wind blows his parachute, causing him to fall into a crevasse. A rescue aircraft flies through the sky. Man on surface runs to supply kit and uses a colored gas/smoke to attract attention. Two men drift down from rescue air craft . One of them descends into the crevasse with a harness, he checks the guy who fell in earlier and gives first aid.The two men above talk into radio. The rescue aircraft hovers over the crevasse, lowering a large basket. The man who fell in in hops into the basket and is pulled up into the air craft.Lowell talks to the camera and announces next expedition in Africa. Shots of various people and animals in Africa. Credits begin.; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive
Lowell Thomas says, "Hubert Wilson, a legendary during his lifetime."; Format: 35mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

Lowell Thomas travels through the north, first on a ship which delivers supplies to various military bases, and then by plane to station A which is only 300 miles away from the north pole. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

Lowell Thomas interviews a man in an airplane. Cut to Lowell Thomas and team of scientists collecting ice samples in Alaska. Next, scientists prepare to launch rockets from a platform. Lowell Thomas and Lowell Thomas Jr. are seen watching. Scientists prepare viewing boxes so that they may watch a solar eclipse.; Format: 35mm; Picture: Black & White; Audio: ; Type: Positive

Following the High Adventure with Lowell Thomas title screen, Lowell Thomas speaks on camera about how the National Defense had been working on expanding their radar program across North America to ensure the safety of the country from any enemy missiles or airplanes. He travels to the Arctic where Lowell Thomas Jr. walks around with a soldier, learning about their daily life and taking a look at their radar. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

The film shows a rescue mission of a man who got pulled into a crevasse my his parachute. According to Lowell Thomas, it is the first time a helicopter has pulled a person out of a crevasse. As the film reverts to just audio, Thomas describes the military's radar and rocket practice. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color, N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive
Lowell Thomas and 3 explorers walk off plane. Different shots of them. Two men open door and see group playing instruments.; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

Man ejects from aircraft and parachutes down. Another man ejects but the wind blows his parachute into a crevasse. A rescue plan flies overhead. The man sends a signal, capturing the air craft's attention. The rescue crew parachutes down. One goes into the crevasse to help the man who fell in earlier. The two men above radio the aircraft. The air craft lowers a basket into the crevasse and lifts up the injured man. Lowell Thomas narrates about defense systems, drones, and missiles. Credits begin.; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

Full episode of "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" in the Arctic. Directed by Bruce Anderson. Produced by Lowell Thomas, Jr. under executive producer Lowell Thomas. Lowell Thomas, Jr. visits a DEW Line radar site. Lowell Thomas, Sir Hubert Wilkins, Burt Balcombe [?], and Donald McMillan visit Eskimos and scientific outposts on their way from Point Barrow, Alaska to the North Pole. "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas." Lowell Thomas is on a ship with his crew. They sail towards Zanzibar so they can sell their pearls. Lowell Thomas collects cloves from the clove orchard. Cut to Lowell Thomas in Australia. He meets with Aboriginese men and they show him how they live off the land. They help Lowell track down the body of a missing man (Harold Lassater) in the desert.; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

Lowell Thomas narrates the last leg of his 6 week and 4,000 mile journey travelling with African merchants in which they bargain for salt in Sheba and sail to Zanzibar to sell their pearls from the Persian gulf. He briefly describes games that are played including Arabian stick ball and bull fighting, introduced by the Portuguese. From there Thomas travels to Alice Springs in the Australian Outback to find Harold Lasseter, a traveler who had disappeared in the desert. He describes the Aborigini lifestyle including their hunting weapons (the boomerang, used to paralyze animals, and spears made from emu thigh bone) and how they find water. In the end of the film they discover a skeleton where a local man said he had seen his people bury Lasseter's body and a doctor confirms Lasseter's identity. A monument for Lasseter is placed in Alice Springs.; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: ; Type: Positive

A High Adventure with Lowell Thomas explores the lives of primitive men and intriguing animals in Australia. Lowell visits the famous landmark Uluru or Ayers rock, which is believed to be the beginning of the world for Australian aborigines. Lowell Thomas takes a team with him to help solve a great Lasseter Mystery.; Format: 35mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Optical; Type: Negative

One of the guide men pulls up dirt and smells it. All of the guide men dig into the earth with shovels, unveiling water. They fill buckets with water and load them onto the vehicles. Lowell Thomas talks about different animals such as koala bears, iguanas, and emus. One of the guide men shows Lowell Thomas a stone covered in markings. Lowell Thomas asks questions about it. He is then showed a cave before sitting down and talking to one of the guide men about Lasseter. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

Tribal man teaches his sons hoe to make fire. A group of tribal men return with kangaroos slung over their shoulders. They cook them. A ritual is performed. In the next scene, a vehicle drives through the desert. A wheel gets stuck but they resolve the issue. Expedition crew briefly stops for a break before continuing. They stop at Ayers Rock and pick up a lizard. They set up camp and Lowell Thomas talks about the species of lizards they encountered. They continue driving, aiming to find water.; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

Man mines rocks. Men clear branches and twigs so vehicles can pass through. They continue driving through the wilderness. The expedition crew speculate where Lasseter's grave could be. The tribal guides say they buried him by a tree with a branding. One of the guides walk up the tree and start hacking at it with a knife. They don't find the branding. One of the tribal guides walk to a specific spot, claiming that's where Lasseter was buried. Lowell Thomas follows him and calls over the rest of the crew. They begin to dig. Lowell Thomas asks a man how they'd be able to tell the body truly belongs to Lasseter.; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: ; Type: Positive

Lowell Thomas talks about Australia. An airplane flies through the sky. Lowell Thomas talks to the pilot. Shots of different newspaper articles. Lowell Thomas exits the plane. Lowell Thomas talks to the camera before pointing to a group of men who use sign language to communicate among themselves. Vehicles drive through the wild. A few different Clips. The first was footage of LT with a group of Aboriginal men who were showing him a sacred rock where a initiation into manhood ceremony was held. The ceremony consisted of story telling and other rituals. No women where allowed in the vicinity of the rock. The second clip included different shots of exoitic animals, including an iguana, koala, and a coco bird. LT narrates this footage. the last clip is a collection of scenes of safari trucks going through large puddle and eventually getting stuck; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

Audio of 83.12A. LT speaking to an Aboriginal man who is describing a sacred rock that takes part of a male initiation ceremony. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

LT on an expedition with a group of Aboriginal men in the outback. First couple shots are of a traditional Original cooking of meat in the sand. Footage also includes shots of traditional aboriginal dancing. LT and the Aboriginal men (as well as a collection of white men) set of in a couple of safari cars. Some get stuck, but they manage to get them out. There is footage of the men setting up camp. and LT narrates this process with music. LT notes that in the outback there is a concern for water shortage. They run low on water, but a Aboriginal man is able to find under ground water by smelling the soil. One Aboriginal man leads LT to a sacred site that the Aboriginal believe their ancestors came from. In the last couple cuts LT and the group of men appear to follow a old treasure trail. One older aboriginal man shows them a cave that has prehistoric paintings on the walls.; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive
Lowell Thomas and his crew are in Australia. They drive around and explore. We see the Aboriginal people hunt kangaroo and build a fire.; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

"High Adventure with Lowell Thomas". (first reel) In this episode, Lowell Thomas travels to the Congo and visits with four European men who have chosen to live there: Prussian crocodile and hippopotamus hunter Erik von Hippel, Belgians Paul Laloupe and Chris Polee, and British anthropologist Colin Trumbull, who studies Pygmies.; Format: 16mm; Picture: Black & White; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

did.unittitle: HAWLT Belgian Congo - "Mountains of the Moons"

scopecontent.p: Full episode of "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" in the Congo. Produced by Milton A. Fruchtman and Willard Van Dyke under executive producer Lowell Thomas. Lowell Thomas visits with four European men who have chosen to live in the Congo: Prussian crocodile and hippopotamus hunter Erik von Hippel, Belgians Paul Laloupe and Chris Polee, and British anthropologist Colin Trumbull, who studies Pygmies. He watches as the Pygmies search for honey, a young man is initiated into the Leopard Society of ritual killers, and then he climbs the Mountains of the Moon. Copyright 1959.; Format: 16mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive
The audio records a tiger, an engine, birds, bubbling water, children laughing, a man calling out, and people talking. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical, Magnetic; Type: Positive

did.unittitle: FX TRK Belgian Congo "LT High Adventure"

scopecontent.p: On the audio track you can hear water sounds, animal sounds and you can hear people talking in another language.; Format: 35mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive
On the audio track you hear water sounds, man talking in another language, animals sounds and you hear birds chirping. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

LT interviewing an anthropologist in the Congo. The anthropologist is studying the "leopard society". This is a secret society that authorities have tried to repress for many years. They are a group of men that live in the forest and identity with the leopard. They wear leopard skins, and skill people using metal claws. They have a stick that they use to make paw prints around the body of the victim. They also eat parts of the body of the victim. LT is interviewing the anthropologist outside a tent. LT then narrates footage of a boy being initiated into the leopard society. First he is given cuts on his stomach that look like leopard scratches. They man who gives him the cuts, chews a herb that will prevent the cuts from becoming infected. The boy is told to wait, as the men helping in the ceremony leave. The ceremony then becomes a "ritualistic drama". A man comes out of the brush dressed like a leopard. He chases the boy, catches him and pretends to kill him. The boy plays dead, until another man comes and "revives" him. The man dressed as a leopard comes back, and gives his costume to the boy. The boy is then given instructions on how to use the claws, and the stick that makes paw prints. The anthropologist then explains what his understanding of purpose of the leopard society. He says that is a way of preserving tribal ingraty in the face of death. For many African people, the leopard is the symbol of death. LT then goes to "the mountains of the moon" him and his crew climb them. LT says that they are the least explored mountains in the world. There are lakes, lush vegetation and mist. despite being on the equator, these mountains have glaciers. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive
On the audio track you hear people singing and different music and different instruments being played.; Format: 35mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

The beginning of the film has a short clip where Lowell Thomas talks about going to Shangri-La but the in the rest of the film, he narrates his adventure in the Congo. He speaks about crossing ice-fields and volcanoes in the Congo. He meets a renowned crocodile and hippo hunter who had married a village girl and describes him as he leads villagers in a hunt for a hippo who had been terrorizing their boats. Thomas gets a short interview with the hunter who tells of the dangers of the Hippo. Next, Thomas goes to the Pygmies and interviews an English Anthropologist about Pygmy society. He narrates as people smoke their pipes and listen to a man tell hunting stories. Thomas describes boys putting their games to use as they tie a cable across a croc-infested river to get honey for the village. At the end of the film, Thomas leaves the Congo and crosses the Sahara. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical, Magnetic; Type: Positive
African buffalo hunting Belgian Congo in safari - pygmies. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

Visual without audio. First scenes are of a male initiation ceremony. A older man in a headdress paints the boys in white paint. The boys are then given headdresses made of dried grass that cover their face. There is then dancing and drums played. Women watch at the edge of the clearing. The boys are then sat down, two older men come with knives, and the the boys are circumcised, the women cheer. The next section shows a group of boys swinging on a rope, one person on LT's camera crew tries to swing, but he falls off. A group of boys and men head down to the river where they are hunting for honey. They see a tree with a hive, but it is across the river and there are many crocodiles lying around. They find a solution. one man with a rope attached to his wrist climbs high up in the tree. the robe it then attached to the tree, and is used to swing the youngest across the river. The boy then makes a thick rope that is attached to trees on both sides of the river, and the other men climb across this rope. One man then climbs the tree that has the hive. He smokes out the bees and throws honey comb down to the other men on the ground.; Format: 35mm; Picture: Black & White; Audio: ; Type: Positive

Audio of LT describing a trip to the Congo. First he describes a group of men who go hunting for Hippos. Apparently hippos provide an important source of food. LT then describes Belgium expats living in the Congo. One of them is a scientist that runs an anti-venom factory. the scientist hires a local boy to help him extract the venom. LT describes how the scientist trains the boy. when the boy gets his pay at the end of the day, he buys a new shirt. LT also describes a white hunter who is famous in the region.; Format: 35mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

Two audio clips of LT. LT introduces a tracker in the Congo. LT lists of African Colonies that are situated around the equator. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

Audio of LT describing a trip in the Congo. Much of it is hard to hear. LT describes life in one Congolese village. He also takes a trip to a factory/ snake farm that produces anti- venom. LT describe how the venom is extracted. Finally, LT describes a white hunter who is famous in the region.; Format: 35mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

LT describes hunting with Chris, a white man living in Congo. They are trying to hunt Wildebeest. Christ as a Congolese man to help him track the animal. Along the way they see impala as well as other large game. Next, LT talks to an anthropologist that has been living with the Pygmies. LT says the pygmies live in the forest and are nomadic. They use poison arrows to hunt for food, as well as take out their enemies. LT joins them for a smoke on the village pipe, and an elder tells a story in the evening.; Format: 35mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive
the film is entirely silent; Format: 35mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

LT states that he is going to interview for white men living in the Congo. LT says that he is by the "mountains of the moon" in the Congo. Here lives a man who was a captain in the Prussian army during WWI, his name is Erik. He was sick of all the wars in the Europe, so he moved to Congo to get away from the problems of "Civilization". He married the "chef's daughter" and become a well known hippo and crocodile hunter. Although he enjoys living in the Congo, he has sent all his kids to England to get "properly" educated LT goes on a hippo hunt with him. They catch one using a harpoon. LT cites a fact that the hippo kills more people then any other animal in Africa. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

Audio clips from the Congo. First clip is of a man yelling in a Congolese language. Next clip if of LT interviewing an anthropologist. LT asks him what is the strangest thing he is working on, and the anthropologist talks about the "leopard society". This is a group of men that live in the forest and that fully identity with the leopard. They dress in leopard skin, have metal claws to slay their victims. They eat their victims, leaving some of the body behind with a claw marking, as well as leopard tracks around the body. The government has been trying to crack down on the leopard society.; Format: 35mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

A tribal boy slides down from a tree and meets up with others. He gives out leaves/food. The boys are eating. A man sits in the middle of a group of boys and talks. View of the mountains. Two men sit at a small table outside of tents. One of these men are Lowell Thomas. They talk. In a new scene 3 tribal males approach a boy. He is placed on the ground and his eyes are covered with a piece of cloth. They cut marks into his stomach and chest with an arrow. Close ups of marks on chests. A man dressed as an animal takes away the boy and hides in tall grass. Another male searches for the boy. The man dressed as an animal runs away. The captured boy is found and carried away.; Format: 35mm; Picture: Black & White; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive
Sounds of birds chirping, people cheering, bubbles/water, and an explosion. Mostly birds chirping.; Format: 35mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

Sounds of birds chirping. Sound of wind (Not sure). Sound of vehicle being driven on gravel or dirt. More animal noises.; Format: 35mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

Narration about hunting and tracking animals like African Buffalo. Birds can be heard in the background. After some time a wind instrument is played. A conversation/interview with the hunter and narrator takes place. A tribe of forest nomads is introduced. A brief history about them is given along with general information. Can hear nomads speaking their language/imitating animal noises. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

Tribal men capture hippo and reach land. They drag the hippo out of the water. Various shots of tribal people performing various tasks throughout the village. After bathing, a woman puts on clothes. We see the tribal people farming. A man sits at a table, two tribal children bring him a box. The man playfully holds up a snake to one of the children's noses. He positions the snake in the child's hands. In a different scene we see the snake in a cage. The child from before opens the cage and starts poking the snake with a stick. The boy runs away from the cage after the man says something. The boy tries to catch a snake in a tree with the help of the man. In a different scene, a boy takes out a white shirt and puts it on. The captured snakes venom is being put in a jar. Lowell Thomas talking to another man, besides a small camp. In another scene, Lowell Thomas stands in a vehicle with a gun in one hand and talks. Various shots of wildlife follow.; Format: 35mm; Picture: Black & White; Audio: ; Type: Positive

unidentified object on filed, shot of water and forest, bundle of sticks? in water, clapboard, hand holding cigarette,3 men on motorboat, man setting up camera on boat, native walking outside holding spears, native making something, shot of grass ; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: ; Type: Negative

Lowell Thomas stands next to tribal man who is holding a wooden staff. Various shots of tribal people swinging on ropes, playing, and dancing. Shots of nature and strange man dressed as a beast. "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" appears on the screen. Lowell Thomas sits at a table with a map in front of him. He points to different places on the map. Various shots of volcanoes, waterfalls and magma/lava follow. Lowell Thomas talks with an elderly man. The old man takes off his hat. There is a close up of the hat.They continue talking. Tribal men sharpen their arrows/spears then get on a boat, drifting away from land towards hippos. The tribal men thrust their spears into the water. One of them falls into the water and the others rush to get him back onto the boat.; Format: 35mm; Picture: Black & White; Audio: ; Type: Positive

scopecontent.p: Rapid short clips show people in the Congo running a vine across a river, weaving baskets, eating, paddling in canoes and relaxing with the film crew. Lowell Thomas stands with a man who he says is the number one tracker of the village and explains a mask that he holds up for the camera. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

The film showed a man being initiated into the leopard society in Africa. The film was narrated by Lowell Thomas and it showed him talking to another man. It showed a man talking about barbaric cruelty. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

On the film you can see two men getting ready to go hunt buffalo's and you also see the buffalo's. The film is narrated by Lowell Thomas. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

"High Adventure with Lowell Thomas." Lowell Thomas speaks to the camera from in front of a hut in The Congo. He explains to us the geography of The Congo.; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive
Lowell Thomas narrates and tells us of a man from Belgium who moved to the Congo. The man studies snakes and venom.; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

Lowell Thomas narrating a program. He tells us of the beauty and attraction of Africa. We watch natives capture a full grown hippo.; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color, N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

Lowell Thomas interviews a man who tells him about cannibals in Africa who hunt people while wearing leopard skin. We watch a young boy's initiation into the "leopard society." They cut his abdomen to resemble leopard spots. A man dressed as a leopard chases him down. The boy's friend follows them and scares away the leopard man. The boy has been "killed" by the leopard man. The boy can now officially be a leopard-man.; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color, N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

scopecontent.p: Lowell Thomas travels to the Congo where he narrates the local Pygmies way of life. They dance, make poison arrows, make a vine bridge across a crocodile-infested river to get honey, and prepare for their boys' initiation ceremony. A brief shot is recorded of Lowell Thomas speaking with another man about Pygmy society.; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive
sounds of horses hooves ; Format: 35mm; Picture: Black & White; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

On the audio track you hear people who asked different question. A man asked a professor the difference between the coral baby and the mother pearl and the professor gave the history from where they migrated from. You also hear someone else talking about an eclipse and a story was told about a French Astronomer and that he was off with his calculation on when the eclipse was suppose to happen and it made him one month late. The French Astronomer made another calculation for when the eclipse was suppose to happen in 7 years and he build a house and stayed where was. After 7 years nothing happen so he went back home. No one knew who he was and his wife thought he was dead and she was remarried to someone else. ; Format: 16mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type:

The doctor talked about eclipse, radiation from the sun, x-ray channels, x-ray experiments , eclipse firing, aspect channels, test firing, rockets, iron chamber, short wave energy, and where in the sun everything happens. The doctor said that they had questions that they'll need to answer and one of the question he asked was, "are the x-rays from the visible corona or are they from a large measure of the chromosphere?" You also hear Lowell Thomas asked, "captain where are we and where we going?" The captain replied and said, "I'll answer the second question, we better go over to the chart table and I'll answer it there."; Format: 16mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

A man thanks people for the food and gifts that they provided for he and his companions. He thanks Dr. Evans for his explanation of the scientific experiments he will be conducting on the sun and then explains his own experiments. He states that he will be firing off rockets (about 150 miles up) with cameras in them that will be able to catch colors that the human eye cannot see. Lowell Thomas asks this man questions after commenting on the lava lavas that they both got from the local Samoans and the tradition of putting a flower in one's left ear (indicating that one is in a relationship). Lowell Thomas saying they learned a lot from Whiskey Johnny about a group of people and about the Island and how it was born in violence and explosion, volcanoes that thrust up from the bottom of the sea. The same as "killer-waii"on Hawaii. He said they went to Danger Island for Eclipse day, but took the opportunity to find out about the Polynesian people and to find out about the "coralitol." He said that they had found there first authentic "pooka pooka" that didn't come from danger island but from Waikiki, Honolulu. ; Format: 16mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

Full episode of "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" in "Danger Island". Directed by Robert M. Young. Produced by Milton A. Fruchtman under executive producer Lowell Thomas. Lowell Thomas joins the United States Navy and a team of research scientists on a journey to the Pacific island of Pukapuka in the Cook Islands, where they hope to study a total solar eclipse by using rockets. On the way, Lowell Thomas stops in Hawaii to interview female hula dancer "Johnny" Frisbie. Copyright 1959.; Format: 16mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive
SHRUNK; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

On the audio track you can hear people laughing and clapping. You hear water sounds, airplane noise, people talking in a different language and you hear the sounds of something firing. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color, Black & White, N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Optical, Magnetic; Type: Positive

Pukapuka: Lowell Thomas introduces the scientists and naval officers aboard the ship as they put on a goofy initiation, giving men crew cuts while dressed up in big hats and robes. Upon coming to the island, one of their ships gets flipped on the reef and divers are sent in to detonate an area of reef to form a canal. On the island, a professor teaches about a specific coral, and Natives dance, sing in a choir, play cricket, and chase chickens. One of the scientists explains the purpose of the rockets and that night through the worrisome weather, they launch the rockets. Persian Gulf: Lowell Thomas smokes a hookah while introducing the dhow crew. Their journey is played out on a map through Arabia to Zanzibar. Men are shown diving for oysters while others harvest the pearls. While stopping in Maculla, Thomas speaks to Wendy Day and her husband Mark about their new lifestyle.; Format: 35mm; Picture: Black & White; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

The audio records people clapping, laughing, and talking, the humming engine of a plane, and rough winds. Announcements are made for men to stay clear as a rocket is prepared. A person counts down before a rocket is launched. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color, Black & White, N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

The sound of several drums. A single piano chord. An orchestra. Children singing in a group, with a guitar playing along.; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color, Black & White; Audio: Optical, Magnetic; Type: Positive

Lowell Thomas invites people from a helicopter on a beach, to join him in Pukapuka. He narrates a Pukapuka native, Johnny Frisbee, in Waikiki before they head off. Dressed as Neptune's court, the men initiate people into their service. The rocket process is explained and divers are sent to blow up the reef and make a channel for their ships. A Harvard professor explains a type of reef to some students. Native people dance, sing, play cricket, chase chickens, and serve the crew. A man explains the rockets to the Natives and the process of the rocket launch is shown. At the end of the film, Lowell Thomas recaps the adventure. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

The film showed divers swimming by corals, it showed rockets firing. It showed Lowell Thomas and another man raising the explorer flag on danger island. It showed people preparing for a solar eclipse. Showed rockets with camera launching at the eclipse. The film showed people dancing and playing instruments. The film showed Lowell Thomas dressed as an Arab on a boat with other men smoking hookah. Lowell Thomas narrated the film as different even took place.; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color, N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

Lowell Thomas travels to Danger Island in Puka-Puka with a team of scientists to study a lunar eclipse. Greeted by Polynesian dancers, Lowell interviews famous dancer Whiskey Johnny. Team sets up equipment to launch rockets into the atmosphere during the eclipse to take photographs of the sun. Produced by Milton Fruchtman, Directed by Robert M Young. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

Footage of LT on a scientific expiation in the south pacific . Lt narrates the scenes as well. Its is a U.S. navy research team that is going to launch rockets into space with data collecting instruments to measure and take pictures of the sun. The rockets are going to be launched from a ship during a solar eclipse. The day before the launch the rockets are readied, as well as the data collecting devices on the ship that will receive transmissions from the rockets. On the nearby Pukapuka island, there is a welcome feast for the scientist. Local girls fan the sails as they sit and each crabs, and drink from coconuts. The village leader gives a speech of welcome, saying that he is interested in seeing the results of this mission. The scientist give a speech explaining what they are about to do, and the high commissioner from New Zealand gives a speech as well. In the night before the launch, there is one last radio dispatch to the scientist that did not make it on the trip. The day of the launch the skies are cloudy. This is bad news for the scientist that remain on Pukapuka as they need clear skies to conduct their experiment. As the solar eclipse start to happen, each rocket is shot off individually. All goes well, except for the last two that fail to go off. The next day one of the remaining rockets is shot off to record giant soar flairs. The rockets travel at a right of a mile and half per second. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

Danger Island. Title track and music. LT comes into frame sitting in a helicopter. Girls bring LT and the pilot coconuts to drink from. There are girls dancing with grass skirts. LT introduces the navy ship that is moored off of Pukapuka. LT goes over what will be in this segment. LT shows how remote Pukapuka is on a globe. He says that he is going there, with a team of scientist to study the eclipse. Along the way, he also wants to learn about the Polynesians. He first interviews a women from Pukapuka that lives in Hawaii. Her name is "whiskey Johnny Frisbee" , she has an American dad and a Polynesian mom. She left Pukapuka when she was ten. She says that Pukapuka is incredibly isolated, there is barely any contact with the outside world. She also tells LT how the Islands were formed from volcanoes. LT the introduces the ship that carries the rockets that will be shot up the measure the eclipse. He says it is a very modern ship. The rockets will go up 150 miles, and the ship also has helicopter that can navigate over the reefs at danger Island where the ship cant sail. LT says the sailors want to meet the Polynesian girls. LT then interview the captain of the rocket expedition. There is a birds eye shot of the ship. The scientist on board the ship, joined by the sailors then do a skit about king Neptune. They play pranks on the newer scientist. LT then goes to Pukapuka on a helicopter. from the helicopter LT shows there is a ship wreck from a ship that got the close the the reefs. When LT arrives, there is a choir of children singing him a welcome song. LT then talks about the "frog men" divers from the navy that are planning to blow up part of the reef to make Pukapuka more accessible. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

Lowell Thomas narrates his adventure to Pukapuka. He interviews a girl from Pukapuka who had been dancing in Waikiki. She explains the dangerous reef that gave the island its nickname, Danger Island. Thomas introduces the ship and film crew that will be going with him. Solar scientists explain their rocket astronomy and the names of their rockets. As they come up to the island, they blow up Pukapuka's reef to make a channel for them to pull their ships up to shore. The captain then explains their mission to the islanders. On the day of the eclipse, Thomas narrates the launching of their rockets. As they leave, the islanders celebrate by playing cricket and having the children sing for the crew. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Optical, Magnetic; Type: Positive

did.unittitle: High Adventure' - Theatrical Dialog Trk "Danger Island"

scopecontent.p: LT in helicopter. A Polynesian girl brings him a coconut to drink from. LT then is in front of a globe explaining where they were going, he points to where Pukapuka on the globe. First they go to Honolulu to meet "whiskey Johnny Frisbee" who is originally from Pukapuka. They first see a traditional hula dance. Whiskey johnny also does a dance performance. LT then interviews Johnny . He asks why Pukapuka is called "danger Island", Johnny says that it is because of the dangerous reef that surrounds the Island. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color, Black & White; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive
