Brief introductions of different scientists/doctors are given. Shot of shipwreck. Helicopter leaves the ship. Overview of village and graveyard in helicopter's perspective. Natives of the island run when they see the helicopter. Natives give Lowell Thomas and his companion some coconuts. Children start singing. Group of men stand on ship before putting on gear and jumping into the sea.; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

Men swimming underwater with larger tanks on their backs. Fish swim by them occasionally. The men place a bag in a coral reef and swim away. We see a shot above the ocean before water shoots up into the air due to an explosion underneath. Shot of objects placed vertically along the beach. People walk around with baskets of fish. Various shots of boats/ships. A tank rolls along the beach. Men raise a flag on the island. Various shots of men operating machinery/technology. Lastly, men sit around another man holding a piece of coral. They has him questions about it.; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

Shot of sun, then moon, then the ocean. Various shots of different men follow. Lowell Thomas talks about Danger Island and how a total Eclipse will occur. Shot of a statue pans to Hula Dancers. A male and female dance to the beat of the drums. Lowell Thomas asks the female dancer questions about Danger Island after she's finished dancing. In the next scene, a large ship is sailing through the sea. Lowell Thomas talks to the captain. The captain points to places on a map. Various shots of people/groups throughout the ship follow. It ends with Lowell Thomas walking onto the deck and talking about the helicoptor positioned there ; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive
*Head is facing out but tail is accidentally marked "head" as well; Format: 35mm; Picture: Black & White; Audio: ; Type: Positive
Audio track of man narrating. Asks a captain where they're going. Captain mentions chart table.; Format: 35mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive
Audio track. quick strident sound. Clapping. Water running. People yelling in foreign language; Format: 35mm; Picture: Black & White; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

The first 40 feet of the roll was a screenshot of a 'Lens Abberations' sign reading: "The vertical and horizontal lines should be sharp all over the screen. Blurring of the pattern around the margin means the picture will also be blurred. As this is caused by the characteristics or condtion of the lens, no projector adjustment will correct it." The final two feet are spliced tail to tail and are a very short scene featuring men fighting a fire with dramatic music. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: Black & White; Audio: ; Type: Positive

Man sitting in chair. Cut to new scene where a different man is sitting at a desk in an office. He gets up. Two of them are talking. They shake hands. A new man stands in the doorway. One man heads for the door and shakes the new man's hand before leaving. The new man walks into the office.; Format: 35mm; Picture: Black & White; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive
Narration about actions and reactions to things, such as bikes or man made volcanoes , of natives of Danger Island. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

View of the moon, view of a ship in the ocean, ship has several missiles lined up, missiles are fired, a piece of clothing clings to the top of missile in middle, very quick image of the sun or moon; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: ; Type: Positive

View of the moon, view of a ship in the ocean, ship has several missiles lined up, missiles are fired, a piece of clothing clings to the top of missile in middle, very quick image of the sun or moon; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: ; Type: Positive

Narrates about eclipse, a farewell celebration, game of cricket, dancing, and other things pertaining to Danger Island and the astronomers. Closes Danger Island segment and introduces a new place. Briefly describes imagery of that place.; Format: 35mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

Various shots of nature. Brief shot of tribal boys, Next to a river, Lowell Thomas converses with old man. Tribal boys sail in a boat passing by Lowell Thomas and the old man. A tribal man sharpens an arrow or spear. A camera Is being set up on the boat belonging to the tribal men. The boat sails off. They encounter hippos and try to capture them. Once of the men falls into the water. The tribal men on the boat try to make their way to him; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive
Two men converse in a store. Close up of newspaper at end of scene; Format: 35mm; Picture: Black & White; Audio: ; Type: Positive

Audio of Anthropologist explaining leopard society initiation. A boy is cut, and must not flinch. He is then shown by his instructor how the catch and kill a victim. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: Black & White, N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive
Audio Track: Background noise. Lowell Thomas one liners. high pitched noise; Format: 35mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

Clips of footage of LT in the Congo. LT holds a mask, and introduces on of the best trackers in the Congo, who is standing beside him. There are shots of a Congolese village, while LT narrates. Title track and a commercial follow. The there is a shot of LT in front of a rondavel. LT is sitting at a table, and shows the map of Congo, explaining that he is in the north east of Congo. In this part of the Congo there are is a towering mountain range, called the Mountains of the moon by an ancient Greek geographer. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color, Black & White, N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Optical, Magnetic; Type: Positive

Audio of LT narrating the rocket launch in the S. Pacific. LT describes the preparation for the launch the next day. The instruments that will collect data from the sun are placed in on the rockets.When everything is ready on the ship, they all head to Pukapuka to have a feast with the residents of the Island. There are girls fanning the sailors, and they are served fresh crab. The '"chief" of the village gives a speech of welcome, the high commissioner from New Zealand responds to the speech.; Format: 35mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

Audio clips from "danger Island". LT interviewing a scientist about the data that is collected from the rockets. At the feast in Pukapuka, the "chief" gives a speech of welcome, that is translated into English. Then another village elder gives a speech, but this one is not translated. The LT suggest that the scientist gives a speech explaining what they are doing with the rockets. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

Audio of LT narrating eclipse day. He says it is the first attempted of launching a rocket from a ship. In preparation for the launch, all the scientist are at their various stations. The day is cloudy, and the scientist on the shore of Pukapuka are worried, because the pictures they are going to take require there to be sunlight. weather gets worse. This means that their preparations over two years are in vain. But the rockets on the ship can still be launched. The first four go off as planned, the last two have issues, but eventually they are fine. The last rocket is fired the next day, and is able to record sun flairs. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

Audio of LT narrating the Danger Island segment. LT says the sailors are look forward to meeting the "Island girls". LT also introduces the rockets. They each have names such as "Sadie Thomas" or "bloody Mary". When the ship crosses the equator they do a skit. One of the scientist that has crossed the equator 18 times is dubbed king Neptune. Those that have never crossed the equator are "initiated" into the crew by under going various "tests". The ship then arrives at the destination. They cannot go to close to danger Island, because there are coral reefs around the Island that came it impossible to go too close. LT can go the the Island on a helicopter. The residents have not seen a helicopter before. There is a welcome song ready for LT. The songs where introduced by "whiskey Johnny's" father. LT then introduces the "frog men" ; Format: 35mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive
An audio clip of a man asking a question to a professor. The professor seems to teaching them about coral reefs.; Format: 35mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

audio of LT interviewing a scientist about rockets being launched into space to record the solar eclipse. The scientist explains what kind of data these rockets will collect. LT asks what will happen if the rockets malfunction, the scientist says that it will be 18 more years until conditions are comparable to collect these data. But by that time it might not matter because there will be observatories on the moon, says the scientist .; Format: 35mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

Audio of LT in the South Pacific. LT starts by saying that he is headed for "danger island" or Pukapuka in the South Pacific. LT then introduces the the different people he met on the trip. He says there are scientist, army men etc. He also talks about "whiskey johnny" a Polynesian women that gives LT the history of the Island. LT also gives a detailed description of the ship that houses the rockets that will record the eclipse. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

Audio clips. The sound of an engine. Very heavy winds. A helicopter flying. An engine starting up. The sound to the ocean. Background sound of children talking/playing.; Format: 35mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive
Audio track of water rushing and then engine starting.; Format: 35mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

Several different audio clips. The sound of heavy wind, a sound of a machine working. The sound of glaciers crumbling into the sea. The sound of a large crowd clapping. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive
A brief sound of drumming, then silence in all the proceeding cuts. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: Black & White; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

did.unittitle: Danger Island, Rocket, Pix Miscellaneous Trims

scopecontent.p: Different clips of LT on a navy ship in the south pacific. LT interviews a lead scientist who is studying rockets and the solar eclipse. There are many different clips of ship life. There is a scene where the sailors are in costume, LT is dressed up as a king. They seem to be playing pranks on each other. There is also a few clips of a group of diver who are called the "frogmen". There is footage of solar flairs, as well as LT on a helicopter ride.; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

The film showed Lowell Thomas on a helicopter with the pilot. Lowell Thomas narrated the film and he mentioned the eclipse and talks about the sun. The film showed women dancing and it showed Lowell Thomas and other men wearing costumes. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

Men operate equipment/machinery. Shots os sun, moon, storm clouds, and a ship. Captain talking to Lowell Thomas points to a map. Lowell Thomas and captain go on tour of ship. Men assemble rocket. Eclipse occurs and they launch the rockets. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

The film showed people laying cricket, dancing, clapping and singing, The film was narrated by Lowell Thomas.; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color, N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Optical, Magnetic; Type: Positive

On the audio track you hear Lowell Thomas mentioned that the sun is the origin of our life. He mentioned people from different laboratory going to danger island for eclipse day.; Format: 35mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

Lowell Thomas narrates the Eclipse Day on Danger Island from a naval ship. A couple of soldiers on the beach do dances and paint in the hopes of keeping the rain away so the sky will be clear enough for the eclipse. Rockets on the ship are set to fire but a malfunction keeps them on board. Two men run up to fix the firing mechanism before launching one of them. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

Lowell Thomas narrates a short film on Pukapuka waiting for the eclipse. He speaks to a man who explains how the radio antennas on the naval ship receive radiation recordings from the rockets that they will later launch. A Pukapuka style lu'au is shown where the islanders cook, entertain, and fan the film and naval crew. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

scopecontent.p: The film shows bits of Lowell Thomas's journey in Pukapuka, a small Polynesian atoll. A navy soldier is presented with a picture of the eclipse that they had witnessed and large ships are shown leaving the island. On the island, videos of the children dancing and singing in a choir are recorded. A "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" title screen ends the film and credits roll. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

Lowell Thomas narrates as he travels first by elephant and then by train through villages in Assam, India, giving background information on the nation and listening to music as people dance.; Format: 16mm; Picture: ; Audio: ; Type: Positive

Lowell Thomas talking living in India and how they where following them because they were on elephants. He said elephants are entertainment to the children and sometimes the elephants follow them also. He talks about how the villagers in India honored them by having a traditional dance and the throwing of rice. He also talks about Brahma and Hind religious rituals. He also said how elephants are becoming useless for having because they are expensive to buy food for and there are now modern cars. Other people started to talk about how many tigers they have killed. ; Format: 16mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

Lowell Thomas talking about a man eatinf tiger and that it killed a lot of people. He was talking about how they used men and elephants to capture the tiger. You can hear animals screams coming from the elephant and from the tiger. You also hear unknown noises and a gunshot. Lowell Thomas said there hasn't been any killings after the they had caught the tiger. You hear someone else talking about high adventures with Lowell Thomas and at the end you hear singing.; Format: 16mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

Another high adventure with Lowell Thomas. He was talking about India, talk about TV expedition and he talks about how dangerous a jungle can be. He also talks about animals such as leopards, elephants, tigers and snakes. Another man was talking also and he said has been hunting jungle animals for the last 20 years and he also talks about the system of capturing elephants. Lowell Thomas said there is a type of elephant that helps wild elephants. He also said elephants won't recognize man over elephants smells and that they have bad eye sight so man would look like they are apart of a herd. ; Format: 16mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

A guy was talking about elephants and he said how they don't start working until they are 18 years old. The guy was also talking about the Himalayas and how Princes isn't there anymore because India became a Republic. He also talks about what happen when try to catch a jungle tiger and how difficult it is to get through the jungle. He said a lot of people dies form venom snake bites and man eating animals. He refers the man eating animal as tigers and he talks about how they've bee trying to capturing. He also talks about how one of the captains had used himself as live bait to capture the tiger.; Format: 16mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

On the audio track you can hear a man talking about him and his wife trying to put down a tiger. He said he had fired four shots. Two shot went in the chest, one missed and the other shot went into the tigers leg. He said he had left the tiger in the kill shot that night and the next morning the tiger was know where insight. He had went down to the river around 6am and by 1pm the tiger showed to to get a drank of water. He said he had took a shot at tiger and pierced its heart. When he approach the tiger he realized that tiger had an old bullet wound with hundreds of maggots on it. Another man was talking about not being optimistic when hunting a tiger because they don't stay in the same location and they called the tigers man eating animals. There were different people giving different suggestion on how to bait a tiger so they can put it down. Some people talked about how much tiger they had killed and the type of gun the should used to put down the tiger. Close to the end, there was a man speaking in a different language. ; Format: 16mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

scopecontent.p: There was man talking about North Eastern India. He was talking about different locations in India and about other countries that is close by. He also talked about the Himalayas. He also talks bout the capturing of wild elephants and how dangerous it can be. He also said there are different types of animals, some are good and some are bad. They also talk about why people need elephants for exporting and how much they have to capture. One of the guy said that there are special plane that they use to transport the animals to different countries. One of the guy said that African elephants seems to be more dangerous and he talks about a man that had gotten killed by an elephant. He also said it takes about 15 days to train an elephant in parliamentary training.; Format: 16mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

Second part of "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" in India. Directed by Willard Van Dyke. Produced by Willard Van Dyke and Milton A. Fruchtman under executive producer Lowell Thomas. Lowell Thomas visits India, where he learns that a man-eating tiger has been haunting the tea growers. With the help of the Thomas party's elephants, the Indians kill the tiger. Contains commericals for sponsor General Motors Delco-Remy batteries, as well as a preview for the next episode of "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" in Morocco. Copyright 1958.; Format: 16mm; Picture: Color, Black & White; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

scopecontent.p: Lowell Thomas narrates the capture of both a wild elephant and a Bengal tiger. Riding a specific kind of elephant, he and the villagers are able to get up close to wild herds, where a wild elephant is captured and trained to carry men. The training takes a mere 15 days. The villagers plan out their capture of the tiger that has already taken 34 people, praying to their gods for success. He narrates like a sports broadcaster as they surround the tiger's territory and herd him into a net.; Format: 16mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

On the audio track you hear Lowell Thomas talking about a man name Boris who used to live in New York but moved to Nepal because of his name. You hear Lowell Thomas talking about riding on elephants and looking for the royal Bengal tiger. You hear Lowell Thomas talking to a prince about why he likes living in a forest area instead of a city area. You also hear them talking about catching a man eating tiger. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color, Black & White; Audio: Optical, Magnetic; Type: Positive

Audio of LT in India. He starts by giving some information about the elephants. mother elephants are pregnant for 22 months and nurse their young for 22 years. Elephants are only full grown after 18 years, and they are the most intelligent animals after the chimpanzee. LT says that they going to a hunting camp at the foot of the Himalayas. When they arrive they unpack and wash away the dust from traveling. They then go speak to a captain who is trying to catch a tiger that has been attacking tea workers. He even used him self as human bait to lure the tiger to a trap, but it did not work. They look around the forest and see fresh tracks. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive
Lowell Thomas introduces the tiger hunt he is about to embark on ; Format: 35mm; Picture: Black & White; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

footage from Shibam in Yemen, LT is narrating. There is a old man and a girl riding a camel outside the city gates. They get off the camel, and the camels are tied up so that they dont run away. Shibam is made up of mud high rise buildings, LT says there are no streets, only narrow alleyways. There are kids playing in the street. Two boys play pick up sticks. LT says that the child mortality rate in Shibam is 50%. Last, there is a brief audio clip of an elephant trumpeting. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color, Black & White; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

Audio of LT describing traveling by elephant through India. He says that although its slow, they get to see more of India. They pass through villages, and groups of curious children follow them. They set up camp, and the elephants eat leaves on of the trees surrounding the camp. There is storytelling around the camp fire. They go the a market place, and LT describes all the different performers and merchants that are there. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

Audio of LT describing trip in India. They are camped at the bottom of the Himalayas. There are in a jungle, and LT says that the animals are not dangerous as long as you leave them alone. LT then goes to a place to get another elephant for a tiger hunt. He observes how they catch wild elephants using small elephants that are faster. When they have caught then elephant, the whole town celebrates. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

"High Adventure with Lowell Thomas." Lowell Thomas takes us on a journey and gives us short descriptions of the different countries and cultures we pass through. First, he is in New Guinea with the natives. He continues to travel through Australia, the Himalayas (Tibet) and Africa (Morocco).; Format: 16mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

Glorious visit to Shangrila - trip to Belgian Congo - snow & ice, volcanic peaks, forests, jungles, pygmy way of life, jumping from tree to tree. Hunting for honey. Coming of age ceremony. Onto Timbuktu with camels. Palm trees, digging for water. Crossing desert, village square, protecting patients muslim metropolis at foot of atlas mountains. Marakesh.; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

Shiba market, on way to Zanzibar, along coast of Africa, sailing down to Zanzibar, spice island, after selling pearls, bullfight. Now to heart of Australia - safari - search for prospector who disappeared. Rare 'mountain devil' animals, aboriginee life, dig up supposed missing prospector Lasseter. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

They blindfold and tie down the rhino and the same man that shot it down gives it a shot (maybe a tranquilizer?). 1 elephant bathes in the river and the sun sets over it. ; Format: 16mm; Picture: Color; Audio: ; Type:

Men on elephants go rhino hunting. Men layout a large cargo net. An elephant with it's tusks cut is eating grass with men relaxing on its back. Other elephants gather up water and pass it to their riders before crossing the river. A man shoots down a rhino and the tied up rhino is carried on a stretcher across the river and grassy plain into the village. ; Format: 16mm; Picture: Color; Audio: ; Type:
People on elephants chasing a rhino which they catch, blindfold, tie down, and carry away. Film ends with a sunset over a river; Format: 16mm; Picture: Color; Audio: ; Type:

did.unittitle: Hooves: Horse, Samarkan, heavy crowd, circus

scopecontent.p: Lowell Thomas sits with a man in uniform by a fountain and speaks with him for a while. The town gets prepared for a festival of sorts. The buildings are cleaned and repainted and decorative people with poles and instruments march past a decorative building.; Format: 16mm; Picture: Color; Audio: ; Type:

A few landscape scenes of the mountains are played. A parade continues and as bands, soldiers, and decorated elephants are marched down the street. The officials are later shown seated under a tent and a crowd of reporters and photographers crowd around as the camera focuses on the royal building. ; Format: 16mm; Picture: Color; Audio: ; Type:

A parade is shown in process. Hundreds of people are lined down the street while decorated elephants carry officials and soldiers march down the street. Some soldiers fire off their guns in the air as they march. Men, decoratively dressed, bring boxes of gifts. A landscape scene of snow topped mountains is shown. ; Format: 16mm; Picture: Color; Audio: ; Type:

People walking around the street and a man in uniform directing traffic outside of a decorated building with flags from around the world. Many people with face masks, decorative garb, and instruments prepare to walk down the street while some do cartwheels and dance. A few people clean the streets, and hang flags and others are directed by uniformed men on to the sidewalk. Landscape views of the snow-capped mountains and close-ups of flowers are also shown.; Format: 16mm; Picture: Color; Audio: ; Type:

Boys sit and sing around a man playing a small piano and a boy playing a drum as Lowell Thomas and a uniformed man speak to each other and look on. Crowds of people watch a parade of bands, soldiers, and decorated elephants pass. ; Format: 16mm; Picture: Color; Audio: ; Type:

Among a group of boys sitting in the grass a boy stands up and speaks/tells a story. Lowell Thomas speaks with a soldier/general in the street before a parade. People along the side of the street wait for the parade and police stand by to control the crowd. People hose down and sweep the streets in preparation. ; Format: 16mm; Picture: Color; Audio: ; Type:

The film shows people going about their daily business. Men sold their handmade goods in markets, women carried their toddlers on their back while getting fresh water from an open fountain, kids played in the streets, men paved asphalt, people lit candles around a temple, prayed, and listened to a man. The film begins with a blonde man with a clapper and ends with a scene from the inside of a car driving down the street. ; Format: 16mm; Picture: Color; Audio: ; Type:

People are going about their daily routine. They are shown leaving their country homes at sunrise and heading into the town with their goods. In the streets there are mats laid out with produce and other goods. Close-ups are taken of the temple and there are men outside of the temple making hand motions in the air.; Format: 16mm; Picture: Color; Audio: ; Type:

People are about their daily business. Men go to others on the street to get a shave or haircut, mats of shells are laid out, kids climb buildings and chase after the camera, girls with baskets of wood on their backs stand in the streets, women bathe their babies and spin fabric, and men spin pots. A group of nicely dressed men speak and play their instruments before marching out into the street. ; Format: 16mm; Picture: Color; Audio: ; Type:

People are going about their daily business. Kids look out their window as people walk down the street. People go through a market of handmade goods, men sell live chickens, kids play in the streets while men weave mats/baskets. People gather around a temple where a man is passing out incense, and some men sell fabrics from a nicer market near the temple. ; Format: 16mm; Picture: Color; Audio: ; Type:

"Return to Shang-Ri-La" with Lowell Thomas. [Title frame not there, but marked on film at 53 ft.] An elderly Lowell Thomas in the region near Tibet, witnessing its people's brightly-colored outfits, its architecture, and people bathing in the river.; Format: 16mm; Picture: Color; Audio: ; Type:

Students walk in a line over a dirt hill. They make their way to the entrance of a small village. Lowell Thomas stands with three men and addresses the camera. Toddlers wander around while adults herd the strays back to the group. We see women sitting around and making yarn. Men and women of the village perform a dance. Men use goats to help them plow the dirt. The children walk to school. We see them sitting in their classroom listening to their teacher. The village gathers for a celebration of singing and playing drums. Monks are seen on a hilltop. The monks sit together playing instruments and writing on parchment. They come out of a building wearing costumes. Cut to men filling up syringes with liquid supplements. A man approaches a sleeping/dead elephant in the tall Savannah grass. We see shots of several village people wearing different traditional outfits and makeup. Lowell Thomas addressed the camera once more. A man plays the violin and sings.; Format: 16mm; Picture: Color; Audio: ; Type:

Lowell Thomas talking to men in a Tibetan refugee village outside of Kathmandu, Nepal; different groups of people chanting and singing songs in call and response; drums; wind instrument melody; crackling sound (possibly water); discussing tranquilizing a rhino; two men talking in an unidentified language; bird noises with peoples' voices and barking dogs in teh background; a single gunshot; mention of a pink membrane; and leaving the "land of Shangri-la".; Format: 16mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical, Magnetic; Type: Optical, Magnetic
Scenes with optical audio: bulldozer, three people in a room, and a classroom scene with music.; Format: 16mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical; Type: Optical

Lowell Thomas narrating a show on Nepal. He first visits the Tengboche Buddhist Monastery in Khumjung, Nepal at the foot of Mt. Everest after passing through the Namche Bazaar. He then visits the Terai jungle of Nepal with Dr. King to capture a baby one-horned rhino for the Miami Zoo.; Format: 16mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Magnetic
On the audio track you can hear singing (chanting) and an organ, a drum and other instruments being played.; Format: 16mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Magnetic

Lowell Thomas announces his journey to Shang-ri La in Nepal. He gives a short background on the country and its wonders as well as the events that his journey will consist of; the royal wedding of the crown prince, the Hindu festival celebrating Shiva's birthday, and a journey into the wild in search of a one-horned rhino. Before the royal wedding he describes the culture of the people and during the wedding he gives a live description of what is taking place. Thomas explains the Hindu festival before hand and the film ends as he's headed towards it. ; Format: 16mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Magnetic

Ambient nature sounds and birds chirping. The man recording audio yawns loudly a few times. He speaks up and begins documenting his hunting experience. Return To Shangri-LA with Lowell Thomas, written by Robert Hertzberg and produced by Milton Fruchtman and Narrated by Lowell Thomas was about life in Nepal. It showed precession before a wedding ceremony, it showed an ancient hindu wedding ceremony, it showed people honoring and praying to the gods, it showed children learning and it showed the hunt for a baby Rhino. Directed and photographed by Dick Durrance; Format: 16mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical; Type: Optical

On a dirt road where people walk with bundles on their backs and stop to buy things from others who've laid their wares out on the side of the street, groups of men clean and repaint buildings and signs. In between these scenes are landscape views of a mountain range and the river that runs through it. ; Format: 16mm; Picture: Color; Audio: ; Type:

Lowell Thomas describes his experience in Nepal. Tibetan refugees build a life in the villages of Nepal. Describes the life of the Sherpa and their moral codes. Lowell goes on an adventure to capture a rare one horned rhino to bring back to the United States.; Format: 35mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Magnetic

On the audio track you hear Lowell Thomas talking about the land of Nepal, talks about the royal wedding, talks about the Hindu Kingdom and the birthplace of the Hindu gods. Lowell Thomas narrates the royal wedding procession in Kathmandu, Nepal, including the dancers and people who had traveled from all over the country. From the wedding, he goes to search for the one-horn rhino and narrates as the men surround, tranquilize, and move the rhino back to camp. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical, Magnetic; Type: Optical, Magnetic

Showed African men and women rowing boats and then it showed a little boy working. The film was titled "The Land That Time Forgot," an adventure with Lowell Thomas. Lowell Thomas adventure took place in New Guinea. The film showed him talking to another man and the film also showed him drinking beer with another man, it showed him getting off of a plane with other people and it also showed him walking in tall bushes with another man. They both were picking something from off of a tree. The film also showed African men picking berries off of a tree and then it showed African men, women and children walking. The film also showed African women crack opening some type of food. ; Format: 16mm; Picture: Color; Audio: ; Type: Positive

Boats are filmed sailing by. New Guinea natives paddle by in canoes. A native boy lies on his belly while adults cut a pattern into his back with a razor. Native women sort through nuts going by on a conveyor belt. ; Format: 16mm; Picture: Color; Audio: ; Type: Positive

A phone call recording if a girl talking to Lowell Thomas. She was telling him about a message that wads left for him and she was trying to contact him. The message was for an expedition to a country that was running low on food and medical supplies. She was telling him code numbers and the arrangement for an urgent air drop. ; Format: 16mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

Audio only. A collection of different splices of audio. Some of the snippets are of Lowell Thomas speaking and some are of a woman speaking. The subject of New Guinea is a common theme between both of their dialogue.; Format: 16mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

The camera zooms in on a radio. A man with a long white beard speaks to a person off-camera. A group of young boys trail behind him. Cut to church/school bells ringing. Cut to New Guinea natives demonstrating their techniques for cutting down trees and breaking off branches.; Format: 16mm; Picture: Color; Audio: ; Type: Positive

Natives of New Guinea present themselves with their bodies and faces painted black and brown. Men of the village shed bark off of a tree. Cut to the men carrying a giant wooden cage. Men in traditional New Guinea headdresses race each other on two-wheeled bicycles. Lowell Thomas inspects a wooden carving. Cut to New Guinea men marching and banging on drums. The marching soon evolves into a run.; Format: 16mm; Picture: Color; Audio: ; Type: Positive

Tribal men wearing traditional headdresses stand in front of a sign that reads, "Mount-Hagen." The men secure bamboo poles by tying them together with reeds. Lowell Thomas speaks with a man, both of them surrounded by the tribal men. Lowell Thomas and a woman taking photographs watch the tribal men dance. The camera films an entire tribe parade past the camera in their ceremonial clothing.; Format: 16mm; Picture: Color; Audio: ; Type: Positive

Written on leader: "New Guinea." Lowell Thomas is filmed standing on a balcony, the Australian flag waving behind him. A man in a white uniform waves to a crowd from a balcony. Different uniformed groups take turns marching across a field. A large group of New Guinea tribal warriors march across the field. A woman on the radio is relaying a message from Lowell Thomas, who is in uncontrolled territory, to a pilot, who can fly over their campsite and airdrop food and medical supplies. She also relays a message to another person about a group of people crossing the Sioux river.; Format: 16mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

On the audio track you can hear someone saying rolling of camera multiple times. You can hear a man saying Haggin Haggin from golf and that he's requesting a conversation with territorial airline because the transmission to them is not clear. The man was saying that they required an airdrop and that they well use two flare for signaling when they hear that plane is close by. He gave the location of the camp in degrees and also in coordinates. They also said that the pilot have to do pick up the food, what time the plane will leave and when they should arrive for the airdrop. ; Format: 16mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

Lowell Thomas speaks to the camera before showing local/native people painting their faces and dancing together. Lowell Thomas narrating a ritual in New Guinea. A Rare ritual where native men are initiated into manhood. Lowell Thomas describes the [Inga?} people's manhood and marriage rituals.; Format: 16mm; Picture: Color, N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

On the audio track you can hear a man talking about a place called Tamboo and that it's a sacred ground where no women have ever walked, neither an outsider. You can also hear background noise and you hear people talking in a different language.You also hear an instrument being played. ; Format: 16mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

Lowell Thomas interviews Mick Leahy about his work in New Guinea on expeditions to encounter different groups of New Guineans to shift their thoughts away from killing and cannibalism. Multiple attempts at other takes.; Format: 16mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive
Scene marker: "New Guinea, October." Lowell Thomas speaks to the camera and introduces the New Guinea natives. He does many takes of this.; Format: 16mm; Picture: Color; Audio: ; Type: Positive

Audio of an interview discussing a tribal murder in New Guinea. A story of cannibalism. [Biami?]; Format: 16mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

On the audio track you can hear a man talking about Papua, in Eastern New Guinea. He said that it used to be controlled by the British and then it was controlled by Australia. The north of New Guinea used to be controlled by Germany. He said that they were in the eastern district, the sub district headquarter of the nomad. He mentioned that no one knows were the name nomad derived from. He also mentioned a group of young men and that they have a tough assignment. He said that they were on the land of cannibalism and that they are going on an expedition in the east. He talked about a group of people that caused terror, talked about cannibalism and that the people like to taste human flesh and that cannibalism is not a ritual but it's apart of their custom. ; Format: 16mm; Picture: Color; Audio: ; Type: Positive
Lowell Thomas is in a plane speaking to the camera and to a person out of the shot. A clapper is shown with New Guinea written on it. ; Format: 16mm; Picture: Color; Audio: ; Type: Positive

Lowell Thomas is flying over the mountains of New Guinea as he gives a brief description of their mission there. He says that the people of New Guinea have remained untouched by the modern world and that it is their goal to find the Stone Age Man, or the last people in New Guinea's uncharted territory who have remained untouched. He says that the location they are going to is closest to the Nomad river outpost. He repeats this description 3 times.; Format: 16mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

Shots of Lowell Thomas in an airplane. A man presents Lowell with a human skull. Lowell inspects it with a camera man. Lowell Thomas and camera crew exit an airplane. Lowell Thomas says goodbye to the New Guinea natives.; Format: 16mm; Picture: Color; Audio: ; Type: Positive

Lowell Thomas discusses his adventure in New Guinea. Describes tribesmen journey back to civilization, they took a plane for the first time.; Format: 16mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Optical; Type: Negative

Lowell Thomas describes the jungle scenery in New Guinea. A tribe performs a funeral for their lost chief. ; Format: 16mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Optical; Type: Negative

Lowell Thomas talks about his adventure travelling through the world largest island, New Guinea. Discusses tribal traditions a rites, what to expect when visiting these primal people. ; Format: 16mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Optical; Type: Negative

Recording of a Dodgers vs Giants baseball game. Cuts to Lowell Thomas talking about the preacher William A. Ross and his involvement in New Guinea. Discusses New Guinea's 3 Rs, respectable work, religion, and reading.; Format: 16mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Optical; Type: Negative
Sounds of drums playing.; Format: 16mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Optical; Type: Negative

The film showed African men from New Guinea, shooting bows and arrows. It showed Lowell Thomas in an ice field, it showed people on a boat working and singing. The film showed Lowell Thomas on a boat with other men and said that they were sailing across the Persian Gulf and he also mentioned that they had magical names. The film showed Lowell Thomas and he mentioned that he was in Australia in the town of Alice. The film then showed him in a monastery in Central Asia. The film showed him in the North Pole, then it showed him on a camel in the Sahara. The film showed people dancing and then it showed Lowell Thomas in a helicopter and he talked about the captain and the south sea. He invited people to come to pooka pooka . The film showed a lot of elephants and showed Lowell Thomas standing next to one talking about kings and tiger hunting. The film also showed Lowell Thomas getting on the elephant and the elephant pulling him up. ; Format: 16mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

The film showed Lowell Thomas sitting on steps talking to another man and it showed them opening up a map and looking at it. It also showed a man walking up to them.; Format: 16mm; Picture: Color; Audio: ; Type: Positive
Lowell Thomas and a member of his film crew talk and smoke on a flight of stairs in New Guinea.; Format: 16mm; Picture: Color; Audio: ; Type: Positive

The film showed pigs, it showed people sitting down and standing up. On the film you can see a man wrapping rope around a stick so that the pig can't go anywhere and you also see other men pulling pigs.; Format: 16mm; Picture: Color; Audio: ; Type: Positive

New Guineans receiving supplies that are air-dropped into the forest, the carrying them across country. They sent up camp in a tent, and Lowell Thomas and another European male and woman are there.; Format: 16mm; Picture: Color; Audio: ; Type: Positive

Chanting with drums, Lowell Thomas announcing their expedition to New Guinea with all sorts of paper products sponsored by the International Paper Company, birds chirping, chanting, shouting, rushing water, birds chirping, hollow thumping followed by a large crash (possibly someone felling a tree with an ax), man requesting an air drop of food from Nomad to campsite and the ensuing food drop, birds chirping, and chanting with drums.; Format: 16mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

On the audio track you can hear the sound of people talking in a different language and you can hear the sound of different noises. You also heard a man telling what the other men was doing at each cuts on the track. They were cutting woods to make fire, they burned a wasps nest, they unraveled a tent, a man was peeling cane. some men dig holes in the ground for the tent post, some men put on palm branches to make the roof on a house and a man peeled palm leaf with his teeth.; Format: 16mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive
Sound of porters approaching the village. Men talking, and babies crying. 23rd of May.; Format: 16mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

On the audio track you can hear a woman narrator talking about women of a village and how they wait on their men to come back. She said how they walk around 8 hours a day in 100 degrees of heat. She talks about one of the patrol guard tolerates her presence but is not too fond of her. She talks about how they cross a rover that too shallow for a raft so they have to walk on logs to cross the river. She also said that they walk for day without seeing civilization and that the patrols of their world. She said that they take turns picking off leeches off each other. She said that they need the size of a football field so that they can air drop food and supplies. She also said that they needed to being making camps 3 hours before sunset so that the patrols can gathered bushes and other things they need to make it. She also talked about how they had passed a village of people from earlier on and they started to show up and that they have no medical treatment and there was man who was on the verge of losing his arm. She also said that they had the opportunity to wash their clothes because they were stiff with mud. ; Format: 16mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

Footage of the camera men waiting to film. Audio snippets of Lowell Thomas talking about the Biami tribe. Lowell Thomas sits and talks to a friend. Footage of the Biami tribe eating and talking.; Format: 16mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

Footage of the New Guinea village. Little boys feed fruit to a bird. Women of the village feed their children. A man maps out the construction of a new hut for the natives. Lowell Thomas and friends befriend the natives. One man gives the chief a cigarette. Credits roll.; Format: 16mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

The film showed people in water and showed a man on a raft. The film showed people walking in a forested area and carrying things in their back. It showed a man shaving wood and showed women and children sitting down. It showed people cooking, eating smoking and talking. The film showed a man eating a bug and it showed people around the area. The film also showed Lowell Thomas talking.; Format: 16mm; Picture: Color; Audio: ; Type: Positive

On the audio track you can hear a man talking about an expedition with the nomads. He said, "somewhere in this jungle the nomad find a group of people that have never been contacted with." He mentioned that there is one opening and one possible means of escape and it's the river. He mentioned that people there knows how to make their own weapons for the chance of survival. He said boys that play outside of the fortress that is constructed by heavy timbers from the jungle. He mentioned a long house that was deserted and that the habitats were warned and they fled into the jungle before the expedition had arrived. He mentioned that food was running dangerously low and can't be sustained for the work ahead and there was only food left for one more day. He mentioned that they walked for a month and they walked 100 miles a day and they must find the people they are looking for or they would have to cancel the expedition. Instead of cancelling the expedition they took a chance and they came up on another trail that led them into circles. The man talks about two civilization seeing each other for the first time, he talked about cannibals. He mentioned that there was inspection of weapons going on and that there is a word called "hesue" that has not been recorded anywhere. He mentioned a pig that was bought and it can be used to feed the men or it can show the men the power of a rifle. ; Format: 16mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive
People are speaking to each other in a different language for much of the film with periods of animal sounds.; Format: 16mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

On the audio track you can hear background noise of people talking. You also hear a 16 year old boy name Gram talking about his village and his father. He said that there tribe called jigga and that men sleep in a house with other men and that there women sleep with pigs. Gram father was talking in another language and Gram translated for him. He told the story of when he first saw Jim Taylor and his first encounter with him. He thought Jim Taylor was the devil and he was really frighten because he thought he had came to eat them but instead he made friends with him. Gram father said when they had first seen airplane flying in the sky, they thought it was a bee. They were asking him questions about when he went into the plane, where they went, and what his life was like before Jim Taylor came along, if his life changed and what he does during his day. You can hear people making loud noises, singing, chanting and playing drums. ; Format: 16mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

At one point a group of people surround a hunched over man. At the end of the film they are settling down and bringing out plates of food.; Format: 16mm; Picture: Color; Audio: ; Type: Positive

The film showed a woman holding a clapper board and it showed Lowell Thomas talking. It then showed him talking to another man and there was people behind them wearing traditional outfits.; Format: 16mm; Picture: Color; Audio: ; Type: Positive

On the audio track you can hear Lowell Thomas talking. He said that they were in the mountains of New Guinea and they were up about 7000ft in the Igna counrty. He said it was one of the largest country and it inhabits between 2 million and 3 million people. He said that Igna people are broken up into tribes and for thousands of years they had war with each other. He mentioned about them speaking pigeon English and that it is referred to as sing sing. He also mentioned different ceremonies that takes place in New Guinea and one of the ceremony they were having was the celebration of the building of a bridge and that the bridge signifies peace and that it takes the people into the present and it takes the expedition into the past. He also mentioned that there was another ceremony taking place and it was for young men that would transition to man hood. He had an interview with a man name Mick and he was from Australia. He talks about a mock battle and talks about how the people are not longer at war, h also talks about traditions that are still present and the dangers around the nomad patrol post and that's where the expedition is working. He said danger of the past still present in New Guinea. Igna believes that women are dangerous and that men should be purified of anything that women have touched including food and clothes and that the men shouldn't have any type of contact with them because the if they do their purification won't be successful. ; Format: 16mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

On the film audio track you can hear people talking in another language, you hear background noise of animals and different noises. He talks about people being involve in a riot and he talks about not having anyone to do interpretation, and he talks about different locations of the different groups of people who lives there. ; Format: 16mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

The film started with a large group of painted men wearing clay masks, feather and flower headdresses. After that the film centers around the craftsmanship of the people who put together the decorations for their night time event. Men are shown painting each others bodies while building their masks. A woman sews together a large garment while a young boy sits beside her. A group of men from each generation (an elderly man, a man appearing to be in his 30's, and a young boy) sit together melting coal and paint onto a decorative object. The ending scene returns to the event where the men dance with torches. ; Format: 16mm; Picture: Color; Audio: ; Type: Positive

Full episode of "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" in New Guinea. Directed by Lee Robinson. Executive producer Lowell Thomas. Lowell Thomas travels to New Guinea to observe the native New Guineans, including canoeing, crocodile hunting and an initiation ceremony. He then meets up with Australian Peter O'Sullivan, who is intervening in a war and kidnapping between two cannibalistic tribes.; Format: 16mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

large group of people in ethnic ware, view of lake and town on horizon, mountain landscapes, people assembling raft, boathouses on lake, people riding down lake, large group of children in ethnic wear, men with bows and arrows (?); Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: ; Type: Negative

did.unittitle: Odyssey Sepik R5 B Track Narration Mag Trk

scopecontent.p: High Adventure with Lowell Thomas opens the film with Thomas speaking to the camera about past adventures and invites them on to the next one in New Guinea. The crew gets their soldier guides and a warning of cannibalistic tribes from the Australian government. they stop in a village where men hunt baby crocodiles that are watched over by women weaving baskets. Boys are initiated into manhood through shows of courage and are taught the messages sent by the talking drum. As the crew moves down the river they meet Peter O'Sullivan who is trying to make peace between cannibalistic tribes. He convinces some villagers to avoid another war by returning a woman whom they had kidnapped from another tribe.; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

"High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" opens with short clips from several different lands and a scene of Thomas speaking to the camera before delving into the episode based in New Guinea. Guides take the crew down a river where they meet Peter O'Sullivan in a riverside village. They escort a kidnapped woman back to her home village and return to theirs where they show the village boys' initiation into men. Scenes are also shown of people paddling their canoes and beating a palm into food. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color, Black & White; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

"High Adventure with Lowell Thomas." Lowell Thomas tells us about his many stops in several Russian cities. He begins in Siberia. Next, he finds himself in Leningrad.; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color, N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Optical, Magnetic; Type: Positive

LT's trip in New Guinea. Opens with LT describing the expedition. LT and his crew will be traveling into the the interior of New Guinea to where the Australians have not been able to "control" apparently it is dangerous there, and few people travel there. They will be traveling in a river boat. They are given New Guinean police for protection. These police know the river well, so can also help navigating. A white official gives the crew a speech, warning of the dangers that lie ahead. He also gives them advice of things that they should not do around the local people. They load up the River boat with 5 weeks worth of supplies. LT's crew is mostly Australian. They first head up the Sepik river. eventually the river narrows, and they have to navigate carefully. A crocodile hunter joins them to serve as a guide. They stop at village to trade for fresh fruit. The local people show how they hunt for crocodile without guns. The Crocs are then kept alive, tied to the side of the house until it is meal time. In this village women are skilled at weaving baskets that are used for almost everything. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive
The audio records people chanting/singing and speaking in a different language as well as bird sounds.; Format: 35mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

Lowell Thomas narrates their adventures through New Guinea and the Soviet Union. In New Guinea, he tells the story of their trip up the Sepik and May river where they meet tribes in the middle of their manhood initiation and Peter O'Sullivan who is trying to get warring tribes to make peace. Thomas details their travel to the Soviet Union and explains the history of the castle built by Peter the Great in Leningrad. He also praises the circus which is the number one form of entertainment in Russia. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

On the audio track you hear Lowell Thomas talking about Cinerama and how he played a key role. He also talking about New Guinea and boys transitioning into man hood.; Format: 35mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

He talks about men young transitioning from boys to man hood. You also hear another man talking in another language. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical, Magnetic; Type: Positive

Beginning with the High Adventure theme song, Lowell Thomas describes the journey that he and his crew will embark on in the uncontrolled territory of New Guinea, stressing the barbarity of the savage, cannibalistic Stone Age men. Guides are picked out by an Australian head of office who describes the terrain to Thomas and warns of the cannibalistic country he is going to enter and how he is to conduct himself while there. Lowell Thomas interviews one of the guides who leads them down a river in his native tongue. Thomas also names the members of his crew including the Australian WWII vets who accompany them. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

Two different cuts. The first cut shows a large wooden boat on what appears to open water of a ocean. There are 3-4 men in the water by the boat. Each of these men are attached to rope that is being held by other men who are on the boat. The men in the water have their noses' being pinched together by a peg-like contraption. The men in the water then dive under the surface. The camera man follows along, and show what is happening underneath the surface. The men swim to floor of the ocean, and collect oyster in baskets attached to their side. The footage then show the men on the boat pull the rope, and the men are pulled to the surface and on to the boat with the baskets. The oysters are then shucked and pearls are extracted and given to a man dressed in white who collects them in a piece of fabric ; The second cut shows a group of men on camels. some men carry spears, while the others carry guns. They ride at a fast pace through a remote and dry landscape. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: Black & White; Audio: ; Type: Positive

On the audio track you here a man talking about flying west from the south east to Siberia. He said Siberia is a country of about 100,000 people and Siberia is a land of which they knew little about. He gave different locations from where people can fly from to get to Siberia. Two of the locations were from Russia and Alaska. He mentioned the Amur River, China, principle port, city of energy and vitality. He also mentioned meeting young people and children from a nursery school dancing for them. He talked about flying deep in the Siberian forest and that Siberia have one of the fresh water in the world and that Siberia is the land of surprises. He also mentioned that houses in Siberia looks like old mother Russia. He mentioned a hydro electric plant, timber, minerals and that Russia calls Siberia the awakening giant. He said that they are potentially the richest country in the world. He talks about the Soviet people and there most popular entertainment comes from the circus. He mentioned making a trip to Central Asia but stopping in Russia first. He mentioned Peter the Great, World War II and the imperial is still honored by Russia. He said the Red Square isn't just the center of Moscow and every Soviet wished to visit there one day. He said that you see one or more wedding party for the day at Red Square. He mentioned the Cathedral that was ordered to be built by Ivan, he mentioned Marco Polo. the rising and falling of empires. He talked about different countries all over the world and wanting to be send back to Siberia. ; Format: 16mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

The film, set in Russia, starts with the replacement of the military guard outside of a large building. A large portion of the film records a circus which includes lion taming, acrobatic tricks, decorated horses, and dogs playing soccer with a balloon. In another scene, a piece of a huge bell is broken off and military men on motorcycles lead a flagged, black car to the scene where men get out to investigate the damage. Other miscellaneous scenes like people walking through a metropolitan street, people socializing on ferry boats, men fishing on a shoreline, and scenes from a plane ride with Lowell Thomas and the film crew are shown. The film ends with Lowell Thomas getting off of the plane with a large crowd of people. ; Format: 16mm; Picture: Color; Audio: ; Type: Positive

scopecontent.p: After opening scenes of Lowell Thomas speaking to women in St. Petersburg, the crew travels south of Moscow where they immerse themselves in a more Islamic society. They capture a royal parade and wedding procession. People perform in costumes in the streets as dancers and acrobats. Thomas is then shown rhino hunting while riding elephants and the rhino's horn is cut off. In the ending adventure, Thomas lands in a helicopter on the island of Pukapuka and invites viewers to join him. In a separate scene in front of a globe, he locates the "Danger Island" in Polynesia and describes the coming eclipse. In Waikiki, HI, Thomas speaks to a Polynesian dancer about the Pukapuka and how people will react to the big boats and planes they will be taking to get there. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: ; Type: Positive

scopecontent.p: The rooftops of Trabzon, Turkey are filmed. The camera films a ceramic pot store in the marketplace. Lowell Thomas Jr. hikes up a trail. Cut to him scaling up the side of a mountain. Oxen pull wagons full of grass, women and children. We see a sign that says "Trabzon- Iran Transit." Another sign says, "Demokrat Parti." A man carries a goat over his shoulders. A car is stopped on the side of a dirt road, standing next to it is a man and his children.; Format: 16mm; Picture: Color; Audio: ; Type: Positive

A man name mark said the population of the region in Arabia is about 10,000 people. They also talk about other region and the economy. Mark function is to bring new method of fishing. Lowell Thomas gave two book title suggestions to Wendy. He mentioned women that looked like Halloween witches, he also mentioned skyscrapers, children with strong stomachs. You can hear music in the background and Lowell Thomas also talk about life in Arabia, the things that takes place. He also mentioned African slaves, gold and clothes.; Format: 16mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

Full episode ot "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" aboard a dhow from the Persian Gulf to Zanzibar. Directed by Jean-Philippe Carson. Produced by Lowell Thomas, Jr. under executive producer Lowell Thomas. Lowell Thomas sails with the pearl-diving "sons of Sinbad". On the way, they stop in Dubai, Mukkallah in Yemen, and Hadhramaut. Lowell Thomas also interviews Wendy Day, daughter of American author Clarence Day, who lived in the region. Once in Zanzibar, the sailor sell the pearls and Lowell Thomas witnesses a bullfight/ bull baiting and visits a clove farm. Leader where commercials should likely be. Copyright 1959.; Format: 16mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

Footage from LT's trip on a Dhow around the Arabian peninsula to Zanzibar. LT introduces the film sitting on day dressed in white ropes and an Arab headdress. He is sitting between to the the ships leaders, they are from Oman. LT is smoking a hookah, and explains that he is journey a merchant ship sailing for Zanzibar along an ancient trading route. He says that this is the first time this trip has been filmed. They will be buying pearls to sell in Zanzibar, stopping at several ports along the way. The sailors are woken up in the morning by a person yelling to get up. They wash before prayer after the call to prayer in Arabic is heard. They meet a pearl diving fleet. They divers do not use modern diving equipment. All they have are wights, a rope to pull them up and wooden pegs on their nose. They dive up to 70ft and stay done for more then two minuets before being pulled up. They have baskets where they put the oysters they find. Oyster are shucked to look for pearls, the captain of LT's ship buys most of the pearls that are found. They then stop at Dubai. LT says that Dubai was once a pirate fortress. The pirate built Persian buildings that had "wind towers" . These wind towers were open of all four sides, and caught the breeze, channeling it down to the living spaces below. They serve as a form of are conditioning. Dubai is also the place the many Dhows are built using teak wood from India. In a square in Dubai, street performers reenact a sword fight. As they are about to leave Dubai, another merchant comes on board. He brings with him food, and carpet and flower for decoration. His mysterious cargo is put under the deck, LT says it is probably hashish. An ex-slave makes food for the crew and LT in a wood burning stove on deck, using fish that was caught from the Dhow. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

Lowell Thomas describes the sea-faring trip he will be making with Arabic traders, in their dhow, to sell pearls in Zanzibar, emphasizing that this will be the first photographic record of such a trip. After naming the crew and describing their devotion to Allah, he describes the pearl divers that they will be meeting and buying from. The diving, also recorded, takes divers 70ft deep where they stay for around 2 min. The pearls are sold to the captain and the crew will take them to sell in Zanzibar for much more. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

LT describing a trip on "Dhow" boat, a traditional Zanzibar boat. there is footage of life on the boat as they travel from the Arabian peninsula, to Zanzibar. There are calls to prayer on the boat, as well as scenes of the ships chef preparing lunch in a wood burning oven. There are also clips of men diving into the ocean from the ship to collect pearls.There is also a blind man on the boat that plays music for the crew. The dhow stops at a port on the Arabian peninsula, there are scenes of the city there, with children playing in the street. There are also images of mapes to show the route where the dhow is headed. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

scopecontent.p: The film showed a large crowd of people gathered around welcoming a monk. Film also showed people in snow and some of them were riding on horses. The film showed people on boats and showed other people trying to get on. The film also showed people carrying long poles, marching, playing instruments and showed people dancing while playing a drum. ; Format: 16mm; Picture: Black & White; Audio: ; Type: Positive
Enormous throng of people walking, people offering white scarves, and His Holiness the 14th Dalai Lama walking.; Format: 16mm; Picture: Black & White; Audio: ; Type: Positive

Lowell Thomas talking about Danger Island. He said it's 2,300 miles south of Hawaii. 6,000 miles west of South America and 4,000 miles in between water and the Antarctic continents. He said they went to Danger Island because scientist had decided that there will be a total Eclipse and they wanted to get vital information concerning the source of our energy and the origin of our life and the sun. He said that the scientist believes that the sun and the moon would cast their shadows on Danger Island which will create the Eclipse. He also said Danger Island is a lost pin point in the vast of the Pacific Ocean. So he invited people to sail the South Sea on an expedition that includes the U.S Navy, Polynesian girls, a group of scientist, the moon etc... on Monday night January 19.; Format: 16mm; Picture: Color; Audio: ; Type: Negative

A man talking about different things like baseball, China's invasion in Tibet and a commercial for general motors delco batteries. ; Format: 16mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

Lowell Thomas interview of Peter Aufschnaiter, author of "Eight Years in Tibet". He illustrates a time when he built bridges and irrigation canals for the Dalai Lama.; Format: 16mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

Lowell Thomas shortly interviews an Eastern Airline Employee who is currently teaching Tibetan children English but doesn't know Tibetan herself. Much of the footage is her teaching in action with the children repeating simple phrases after her. Lowell Thomas then speaks about heading into the jungle with his guide and looking for exotic animals, describing a few that may be dangerous.; Format: 16mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

did.unittitle: Lowell Thomas Jr. Original Robert Siam

scopecontent.p: Footage of monks visiting an elaborately decorated temple. Inside there are religious statues and lit candles. Scenes of farmers tending to their crops. The field is swampy, and they use longhorn cattle to help plough the fields. A man carries the crops on his shoulders. There a man dressed in a traditional costume wearing a mask and dancing in front of musicians playing various instruments. Two women wearing colorful costumes are also dancing together [Hindu or Buddhist tradition?]. A large crowd sits in the stands to watch a boxing match between two young men.; Format: 16mm; Picture: Color; Audio: ; Type: Positive

The film starts off with an overview of an location then it cuts to people riding bicycles and driving cars. A building is being showed and then the film shows people selling and buying things. There was a woman walking on a rooftop and then then the film goes to a man herding sheep's. The woman was trying to get a sheep attention but the sheep wasn't paying her any mind. The film shows a man riding a camel and the camels are carrying loads of baggage. The film also shows a donkey attach to a water system operating it by walking in circle with sticks connecting the donkey and the machine. Part one of "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" episode in Tibet. Narrated, produced, and directed by Lowell Thomas and Lowell Thomas, Jr. An Odyssey Production. Lowell Thomas and Lowell Thomas, Jr. are granted permission to enter Tibet prior to China's invasion. This film follows their journey across the Himalayas from India into Tibet, as they make their way to Lhasa in time for the summer festival. Contains introduction by Lowell Thomas.; Format: 16mm; Picture: Black & White; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

Part two of "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" episode in Tibet. Narrated, produced, and directed by Lowell Thomas and Lowell Thomas, Jr. An Odyssey Production. Lowell Thomas and Lowell Thomas, Jr. arrive in Lhasa to meet His Holiness the 14th Dalai Lama and film him for the first time. On the journey home, Lowell Thomas breaks his hip [really his leg just below his hip] in eight places and must be carried back to India. Contains conclusion by Lowell Thomas.; Format: 16mm; Picture: Black & White; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

Audio only. Lowell Thomas is speaking to us from the Dalai Lama's Palace. He describes the palace for us in detail. Then he changes subject and discusses how he fell in love with production and adventure films. He wants to convert Cinerama movies to Television. He passes the focus on to his friend named Pat. Pat speaks of Lowell Thomas' achievements and talents. He discusses plans for new Television program plots. One about new countries that have been established since the end of World War II. Lowell Thomas comes back and goes on to list more movie ideas. Pat cuts him off, claiming they will run out of film. They wrap up, taking about how important and impactful real-world stories could be as entertainment.; Format: 16mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

Lowell Thomas discusses his travel to Tibet with his son, Lowell, jr. They have been invited by the Dalai Lama, but are not able to bring anyone else along with them. He describes the Tibetan people as peaceful isolationists and describes their journey through a small, simple town in the valley, where they meet a military escort. As they get closer to the city of Lhasa, Thomas describes the treacherous baths. He describes the city of Lhasa, calling it the â€˜El Doradoâ€™ of travelers. They visit a monastery with 10,000 monks and he describes their lifestyle. The then meet the Dalai Lamaâ€™s family, and finally the man himself. When they leave, Lowell Thomas is injured by an unruly horse. Lowell, jr. takes over and he describes the rest of the descent from the city. He describes the way that his father is strapped to a litter and carried for the rest of the journey. He details his fathers condition and how perilous it made the journey. Lowell Thomas takes over the end of the recording and credits his son for getting him out of danger.; Format: 35mm; Picture: N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Magnetic; Type: Positive

Clips from both Tibet and the Arctic. The first set of clips is from the arctic. LT is narrating an expedition that he took with old polar explorers to the North Pole. They fly over glaciers and their first stop is a Island of ice with in the arctic circle. The island is a scientific station. LT talks to an Austrian scientist who says he studying how the ice melts. Another scientist speaks about how the ice can suddenly crack, splitting building apart. there are a couple of clips of men in wet suits jumping into the ice water. The trip continues-- LT along with the retired polar explorers fly over the north pole. One of the men is the only serving member of the historic Perry expedition. LT gives a champagne toast to this man as they fly over the north pole, because he has finally reached it after 48 years. LT also drops flowers as they fly over the pole, to honor all those that had lost their lives trying to reach it. Tibet-- the Tibet trip starts in India. LT and LT jr., along with Tibetan porters. load up pack animals in preparation of crossing the Himalayas to reach Tibet. They trek down cliff and over rivers. Everyone gets lice. Footage shows LT trying to wash away the lice in a waterfall. When they reach the first Tibetan village that mayor, who is 10 feet tall, comes out to greet them giving them silk scarfs. In the village they see women weaving and making butter. They see a herd of yaks on on a large plain. They make it to Lhasa. Officials comes to greet LT, and they they will be the hosts.s There is a festival in the city. There are giant horns and symbols crashing. There is a dance performance where the dancers are masked. They go to the largest monastery. there they see monks giving out barley flour to the poor. LT is finally allowed to meet the Dalai Lama. He is on a throne and asks them many questions. They then leave Lhasa via river. On the trek back to India, LT breaks his hip in eight places. He is then carried on a stretcher, and spends many days in pain.; Format: 35mm; Picture: Black & White, N/A - Audio track only; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

The film runs through brief scenes of monks, lamas, and average people walking through streets and monasteries in Tibet. Lowell Thomas tells how only he and his son were allowed to visit the country and so all of the filming was done by themselves. They hike narrow paths and bridges through the mountains and at one point Lowell Thomas is being carried in a litter. Brief clips of the Dalai lama are also taken. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive

scopecontent.p: Lowell Thomas narrates his journey with his son to Tibet. With the stamp of the Dalai Lama and a military escort, the crew backpacks their way into the secluded Tibet. Thomas highlights the lives of the Tibetan people, speaking about the importance of the Yak in their lives and praising their tea gardens as well as their boats made out of Yak skin which can hold up to a ton but is so light it can be carried on a single man's back through the mountains. ; Format: 35mm; Picture: Color; Audio: Optical; Type: Positive
